@Nitrix321 no problem, let us know if anything!

title: How to correctly get tokens that have the same short names, but which are different in essence?
body:
### Operating System

Windows 10 

### Programming Languages

python

### CCXT Version

2.8.31

### Description

For a concrete example, I want to get information about the GAS token on two exchanges, mexc and gate. However, what is called GAS(but GAS here is only the example, there are a lot of same tokens with such names) in Mex is actually GAS_DAO, on the gate the full name of the GAS token is also GAS. This is a different coin with a different price and with a different contract. How can I separate these concepts and get information about GAS(GAS), and not about GAS_DAO. I tried using load_market, fetch_markets and fetch_tickers. I noticed that it's not a bad idea to compare coins by code. But I don't understand how to get a coin by code.(2 part of code). Sorry if this is a dumb question, I'm just really stuck

### Code

```
import ccxt

exchange1 = ccxt.mexc3()
exchange2 = ccxt.gate()

exchange1.load_markets()
exchange2.load_markets()
markets1 = exchange1.currencies
markets2 = exchange1.currencies

print(markets1['GAS'])
print(markets2['GAS'])‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ

Using codes

import ccxt

exchange1 = ccxt.gate()
exchange2 = ccxt.mexc()

symbols1 = exchange1.load_markets()
symbols2 = exchange2.load_markets()

print(exchange1.currency('GASDAO')['code']) #GASDAO
print(exchange2.currency('GAS')['code'])  # GASDAO
```
author: AlwxDavydov

comments.body:
Hi @AlwxDavydov , So ccxt unifies the codes so it's the same across all exchanges. In the case of GASDAO, we use GASDAO.
Also for most functions we accept both the unified ccxt code and also the exchange code. So in the example of mexc, mexc uses the code GAS for GASDAO, this is why you can call both `mexc.currency('GAS')` and `mexc.currency('GASDAO') and both will return GASDAO. As the first will reference the mexc's code for GASDAO and the second case it will recognize ccxt's unified code GASDAO.

This is a bit of a unique case because the exchange code mexc uses is the same as the code ccxt uses for a different currency(GAS).

In the case of gate, it does support both currencies GAS and GASDAO. So `gate.currency('GAS')` will return the GAS currency and `gate.currency('GASDAO')` will return the GASDAO currency.

I hope this answers your question. I'll close the issue for now but feel free to reach out with any other questions!

### Code

node_modules/ccxt/js/src/tidex.d.ts:78:5 - error TS2416: Property 'sign' in type 'tidex' is not assignable to the same property in base type 'Exchange'.
  Type '(path: any, api?: string | undefined, method?: string | undefined, params?: {} | undefined, headers?: any, body?: any) => { url: any; method: string; body: any; headers: any; }' is not assignable to type '(path: any, api: string | object, method?: string | undefined, params?: {} | undefined, headers?: any, body?: any) => {}'.
    Types of parameters 'api' and 'api' are incompatible.
      Type 'string | object' is not assignable to type 'string | undefined'.

78     sign(path: any, api?: string, method?: string, params?: {}, headers?: any, body?: any): {
```
author: MedionSF

comments.body:
Hello @MedionSF, we moved ccxt entirely to Typescript so now, instead of manually generated type definitions, they are automatically emitted by `tsc`. Due to that, some discrepancies might appear for users relying on the old types, but it should be very easy to fix. 

Can you show use the code producing that error?

(as a quick fix you can always temporarily add `skipLibCheck` to `compilerOptions` )

@MedionSF Actually I found the reason, our project does not seem to work with old versions of typescript (<4).
What is your ts version?

> @MedionSF Actually I found the reason, our project does not seem to work with old versions of typescript (<4). What is your ts version?

version 4.7.4

What seems weird is that there is indeed a discrepancy in the params between the abstract class and the concrete classes inheriting it.

I've taken the easy route and removed true casts in favor on any, and require instead of import. But it doesn't feel right :D

@MedionSF I will check that discrepancy but it's weird that our tsc build does not detect anything and I've also configured two different typescript projects (one esm and the other cjs) and  they both compiled perfectly with `ccxt` as a dependency

> @MedionSF I will check that discrepancy but it's weird that our tsc build does not detect anything and I've also configured two different typescript projects (one esm and the other cjs) and they both compiled perfectly with `ccxt` as a dependency

Actually it's true that when checking exchanges ts files I can see:
`sign(path: any, api?: string, method?: string, params?: {}, headers?: any, body?: any)`

While the parent class has
`sign(path: any, api: string | object, method?: string, params?: {}, headers?: any, body?: any): {};`

title: Code returns  NotSupported: huobi fetchTransactionFees() is not supported yet with whom it has worked before
body:
### Operating System

Windows 10 

### Programming Languages

python

### CCXT Version

2.8.31

### Description

I got this error: NotSupported: huobi fetchTransactionFees() is not supported yet with all exchangers that I tried to use. I tried mexc, kucoin and huobi. And if I'am not mistaken it worked with all this exchangers in past. Please tell me is it a bug or It's really not supported right now. And if it's not please tell me all exchangers that support it. Thank you.

### Code

data = ccxt.kucoin({apikey:xxxxxx, secret:'xxxxxxxxxxxxxx'}).fetch_transaction_fees()
print(data)
author: AlwxDavydov

comments.body:
Hello @AlwxDavydov,
`fetchTransactionFees` was deprecated and replaced with `fetchDepositWithdrawFees`.  Can you try to use the latter instead?

---------------

`fetch_deposit_withdraw_fees` for python

Little example of code 

import ccxt
import sys

sys.stdout.reconfigure(encoding='utf-8')

exchange = ccxt.mexc({api:'xxxxx', secret:'xxxxxxxxxx'}) # You can also try kraken and it will retrun the same error KeyError: 'fetchDepositWithdrawFees'

deposit_addresses = exchange.fetch_deposit_withdraw_fee('USDT')
print(deposit_addresses)

@AlwxDavydov That's right, kucoin does only support the `fetch_deposit_withdraw_fee()` function but not the `fetch_deposit_withdraw_fees()` function.

Whenever you use *mexc* you make use of version 2 of mexc's api, version 2 doesn't support `fetch_deposit_withdraw_fee()`/ `fetch_deposit_withdraw_fees()`, *mexc3* does support both tho.

Code example:
```python
import ccxt

exchange = ccxt.mexc3({api:'xxx', secret:'xxx'}) 

deposit_withdraw_fee = exchange.fetch_deposit_withdraw_fee('USDT')
print(deposit_withdraw_fee)
```

If you have any more questions, let us know :)

title: Bid and ask sizes are None for coinbase ticker updates
author: L1nkus

comments.body:
Hello @L1nkus,
I think that `best_bid_size` or `best_ask_size` represent the `best_bid`/`best_ask` volume, not the overall `ask`/`bid` volume.

Hey @carlosmiei ,
> Hello @L1nkus,
> I think that `best_bid_size` or `best_ask_size` represent the `best_bid`/`best_ask` volume, not the overall `ask`/`bid` volume.

From ccxt docs:

The structure of a ticker is as follows:

{
    'symbol':        string symbol of the market ('BTC/USD', 'ETH/BTC', ...)
    'info':        { the original non-modified unparsed reply from exchange API },
    'timestamp':     int (64-bit Unix Timestamp in milliseconds since Epoch 1 Jan 1970)
    'datetime':      ISO8601 datetime string with milliseconds
    'high':          float, // highest price
    'low':           float, // lowest price
    'bid':           float, // current best bid (buy) price
    'bidVolume':     float, // current best bid (buy) amount (may be missing or undefined)
    'ask':           float, // current best ask (sell) price
    'askVolume':     float, // current best ask (sell) amount (may be missing or undefined)
    'vwap':          float, // volume weighed average price
    'open':          float, // opening price
    'close':         float, // price of last trade (closing price for current period)
    'last':          float, // same as `close`, duplicated for convenience
    'previousClose': float, // closing price for the previous period
    'change':        float, // absolute change, `last - open`
    'percentage':    float, // relative change, `(change/open) * 100`
    'average':       float, // average price, `(last + open) / 2`
    'baseVolume':    float, // volume of base currency traded for last 24 hours
    'quoteVolume':   float, // volume of quote currency traded for last 24 hours
}
Notes On Ticker Structure

All fields in the ticker represent the past 24 hours prior to timestamp.
The bidVolume is the volume (amount) of current best bid in the orderbook.
The askVolume is the volume (amount) of current best ask in the orderbook.
The baseVolume is the amount of base currency traded (bought or sold) in last 24 hours.
The quoteVolume is the amount of quote currency traded (bought or sold) in last 24 hours.

I think the wiki says that those fields are meant to represent the current volumes on best levels?
@L1nkus Which method are you using? I'm not able to find `best_bid_size` or `best_ask_size` using fetchTicker of fetchTickers

     print(text)

      'enableRateLimit': True,
      'apiKey':'A',

      'options': {
      'defaultType': 'spot',
        },
        })
                
    

b="CFXUSDT"    


order = exchange.create_order(

  type='STOP_LOSS_LIMIT',
  amount=35,
  price=0.32,
  side='buy',
  params={'stopPrice': 0.32}

author: ctu1121

comments.body:
@ctu1121 in your code you're not reading JSON as JSON, you're reading it as text. Also make sure that you're passing the contents of API.json as `apiKey` and `secret` to the exchange constructor. Apart from that you're missing the `await` keyword with `exchange.create_order`, cause it returns a JS Promise. 

In short, this is not a question on how to use CCXT, but more like a question on the basics of JavaScript / Node.js programming.

If your `API.json` looks like this:

```JSON
{
    "apiKey": "XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX",
    "secret": "YYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYYY"
}
```

Then your code should look like this:

```JavaScript

const config = require('API.json')

exchange = ccxt.binance(config)

b="CFXUSDT"

order = await exchange.create_order(
symbol=b,
type='STOP_LOSS_LIMIT',
amount=35,
price=0.32,
side='buy',
params={'stopPrice': 0.32}
)
```

title: Can ccxt identify whenever API changes are pushed on an exchange's endpoint?
body:
There has been some mention of work being done by this team to unify the ccxt schema amongst all these various exchanges to allow for easier implementations for developers. I am also aware that there are many cases currently where each exchange needs to be handled differently based on what the exchange itself actually supports, such as the _binanceus_ exchange and the _kucoinfutures_ exchange, which use different schemas simply because of the nature in how each exchange trades: spot currencies and purpetual futures contracts. It's a given that when invoking a place_order() function call on both exchanges, it's not always going to translate over 1:1, so I'm trying to figure out the cleaniest way of wrapping code and handling this which has brought a few concerns to my attention.

I was thinking of wrapping various ccxt methods into a base python class and having my various strategy classes inheret from this. This way, using the _exchange_id_ as the unique identifier in the base class, I can write some code to address the differences in each schema and unify it into a single dictionary without the need for a bunch of conditionals in my strategy classes.

However as time goes on, APIs and exchange endpoints can change. If an exchanges endpoint decides to change their schema even _just a little bit_ and it goes above my radar or isn't supported by the newest version of ccxt yet, then it could cause unpredictable behavior in my strategies and potentially cause financial loss if not handle properly. Ideally ccxt framework would update their libraries to keep the schema up to date in relation to exchanges API changes. But if new changes are not yet supported after something been pushed, then is there any way to catch this-- either through manually validating differences in the expected schemas, or perhaps checking for an API version control number on the endpoint?

How could I raise an exception if there an issue between what the exchange provides and what ccxt expects? How can I raise an exception if there are issues between what ccxt's schema provides and what my unified wrapper methods expect?
author: RoscoeTheDog

comments.body:
Hi @RoscoeTheDog, you are right that there is a risk that the exchange might change their API behavior. However this risk would also exist by calling directly the exchange API. To mitigate the risk we do have several things in place. First we try to stay on top of API changes, with certified exchanges there is a direct communication channel between the ccxt team and the exchange team, also the ccxt community helps in reporting any issues and lastly we have a set of tests we run at build time to try and check the functions are working as expected.
If you really wanted to further control for this, my best suggestion would be to write specific tests for your use case, to make sure the return values are what you expect.

Thank you for your response. All of that sounds fairly reassuring. Is there a way I could parse an order dictionary schema in advanced before placing an order on the exchange? I'd like to create a validation method that searches the dictionary for a few keywords which code might rely on for correct functionality. This way, if ccxt ever changes their schema, my code can catch it in advance before the order even goes through.

From the ccxt side, our schema is quite consistent and we always try to be backwards compatible. If you want to run a validation you could write your code in typescript and use `ccxt.d.ts` to run type validation checks during build. However do note that even though this confirms the schema, it does not confirm if for a certain exchange those values may be populated or not, as depending on the exchange they are not always available. Also note, the one place I'd be slightly more cautious is under the 'info' parameters, for example `order['info']` as there we return the raw response from the exchange and will change if the exchange changes their response and is not unified.
Hi @RoscoeTheDog , I'll close this issue for now but feel free to reach out with any other questions

title: python async speed slower
body:
### Operating System

ubuntu

### Programming Languages

python

### CCXT Version

2.6.94

### Description

While I was trying to migrate my code to async I noticed that my execution was slower.

I wrote a small code to compare the async vs sync speed. 

Average execution time of both is written below in seconds in one of my test runs. On average async takes rougly 2x longer . Similar results when tested in other methods such as "fetch_tickers".

async mean: 1.1664345026016236
sync mean: 0.5469205617904663

### Code

```
import asyncio
import time

import ccxt.async_support as ccxta  
import ccxt
import os
from dotenv import load_dotenv
load_dotenv()

binance_keys = {
        "apikey" : os.getenv("BINANCE_APIKEY"),
        "secret" : os.getenv("BINANCE_SECRET")
    }

async def get_balance_async(exchange):
    balance = await exchange.fetch_balance()
    await exchange.close()
    return balance

exchange_async = ccxta.binance({
        'apiKey': binance_keys["apikey"],
        'secret': binance_keys["secret"],
    })

exchange_sync = ccxt.binance({
        'apiKey': binance_keys["apikey"],
        'secret': binance_keys["secret"],
    })

time_sync = []
time_async = []

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
for i in range(10):

    start = time.time()
    loop.run_until_complete(get_balance_async(exchange_async))
    time_async.append(time.time() - start)
    time.sleep(0.2)

    start = time.time()
    balance = exchange_sync.fetch_balance()
    time_sync.append(time.time() - start)
    time.sleep(0.2)

print("Async data: ", time_async)
print("Sync data: ", time_sync)
print(f"async mean: {sum(time_async)/len(time_async)}")
print(f"sync mean: {sum(time_sync)/len(time_sync)}")
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇ

```
author: akasimo

comments.body:
Hello @akasimo,
The difference is not related to the sync vs async approach, but the default RateLimiter ccxt async has in place. You can disable it if you want by providing this option: `enableRateLimit: False`.
perfect, thanks!

title: binancecoinm fetch_positions() returns non standard symbol name for LUNA in sandbox mode
body:
### Operating System

Linux

### Programming Languages

python

### CCXT Version

2.6.21

### Description

ccxt.bianncecoinm.fetch_positions() (and fetch_positions_risk()) return a non-standard symbol name for LUNAUSD_PERP instead of either a) not returning it at all or b) returning LUNA/USD:LUNA.

However, ccxt.binancecoinm.fetch_account_positions() does not return this symbol at all.

This appears to be driven by the underlying binance call returning LUNA as a symbol for the api call fetchPositionsRisk but not returning it for the api call fetchAccountPositions ??? and in turn, LUNA is no longer included in the markets mapping for safe_symbol() for some reason - so the default 'LUNAUSD_PERP' is returned.

I lost it there... not sure what the correct fix would be in order to respect the unified symbol naming convention.

For now, I will use fetch_account_positions() as it seems 'cleaner'.

The code below shows the #62 symbols (with LUNA) from fetch_positions() and fetch_positions_risk() vs. the #61 symbols returned from fetch_account_positions()









### Code

```
‚ÄÇ‚ÄÇimport ccxt 

config = {
    'apiKey': 'b...c9',
    'secret': '9...2e',
}

print('CCXT Version:', ccxt.__version__)

exchange = ccxt.binancecoinm(config)
exchange.set_sandbox_mode(True)
markets = exchange.load_markets()

print("LUNA with non-standard symbol name in fetch_positions()")
positions = exchange.fetch_positions()
print("POSITIONS #", len(positions))
for position in positions:
    if 'LUNA' in position['symbol']:
        print(position['symbol'], position['info']['symbol'])

for position in positions:
    if 'LUNA' in position['symbol']:
        print(position['symbol'], position['info']['symbol'])

for position in positions:
    if 'LUNA' in position['symbol']:
        print(position['symbol'], position['info']['symbol'])

```

title: How to detect programmatically if defaultType needs to be specified when accessing spot and swap market?
body:
### ÿú

Hello,

I  can't find documentation about the instance's option `defaultType` and `defaultSubType` and was wondering how to detect if they need to be set when accessing markets or when sending an order to spot or swap markets. Some exchanges have the options (Binance, Bybit) but not all (Coinbase, Kucoin, Bitmex). Why and when to use them ?

```
In [4]: ccxt.binance().options['defaultType']
Out[4]: 'spot'

In [5]: ccxt.coinbase().options['defaultType']
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-05a53e58eafe> in <module>
----> 1 ccxt.coinbase().options['defaultType']

KeyError: 'defaultType'

In [6]: ccxt.kraken().options['defaultType']
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-6-6940b7a1c511> in <module>
----> 1 ccxt.kraken().options['defaultType']

KeyError: 'defaultType'

In [7]: ccxt.bitmex().options['defaultType']
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-7-3c725d5072a7> in <module>
----> 1 ccxt.bitmex().options['defaultType']

KeyError: 'defaultType'

In [8]: ccxt.bybit().options['defaultType']
Out[8]: 'swap'

```
author: Kinzowa

comments.body:
Hello @Kinzowa,

`defaultType` is an option that helps us to disambiguate between markets from different types (spot and swap for example) but with conflicting ids.

With the latest developments, if you always use the unified symbols, you only have to worry about methods that don't require a symbol (`fetchBalance`, for instance) . Most of the time (bybit is the only exception here), it will default to `spot` when it has to choose between the spot and swap. 

In short, you might need to change `defaultType` here and there to get non-spot information when the symbol is not available, but it should be effortless to set it up.

Hi, Carlos,

Thanks for your answer.

My understanding is that `defaultType` specify an account's type which give access to markets of that specific type. But I'm still scratching my head why, on some exchanges like Kucoin, markets of different types can be accessed without the `defaultType` parameter. Could you please elaborate if it's related to the exchange internal account structure or something different? 

I remember that FTX had a unique account for spot, swap and futures markets, so that no internal transfer of fund were necessary. However, I see that the `transfer()` method is supported by Kucoin whereas this exchange has no `defaultType`'s option, which is a contradiction to me.

BR,
Kinzowa

Hello again @Kinzowa 

As I said `defaultType` is just a little helper on our end it's not directly related to any exchange/account.

Kucoin is a peculiar case because it has completely independent APIs/ API keys/implementations for spot and derivative markets, so it does not need any "help" (`defaultType`). `kucoin` will always return spot info whereas `kucoinfutures¬¥ will always return derivatives-related information. 

Let's say you do this
```Python
bybit.fetch_ticker('BTC/USDT') # spot market
bybit.fetch_ticker('BTC/USDT:USDT') # derivative market
```
‚¨ÜÔ∏è Here, `defaultType` isn't necessary either because our unified symbols are enough to distinguish between a spot or a swap market, so ccxt knows that in the first call, it should use the `spot` endpoint and the `swap` one in the second call.

Now you run this:
```Python
bybit.fetch_balance()
```
‚¨ÜÔ∏è  This is a bit different, `bybit` has different wallets and the endpoint to fetch them is also different, so ccxt has to decide if it should use the `spot` or `swap` endpoint. Since we don't have any symbol available to disambiguate ccxt will resort to the `defaultType` to make this decision unless you specifically provide a `type` inside `params`.

Example:
```Python
bybit.fetch_balance() # will use the defaultType (`swap` in this case) to disambiguate, so will fetch derivative balances
bybit.fetch_balance({"type":"spot"}) # type is provided, so we don't need to resort to `defaultType` and spot balances will be fetched
```

Let me know if you're still not 100% clear on this!
Thank you, it's very helpful. Based on your example I assume that Kucoin has a unique wallet for spot, futures and swap.

@carlosmiei Kucoin has a Main Account and a Futures Account (.i.e. wallets), both with different interface to GET the account or wallet balance. So how ccxt decides which account the `fetch_balance()` method should return without a `defaultType`'s option ?
@Kinzowa yeah, actually kucoin uses the `defaultType`  there

```
both for shorts and longs

### Code

                                   type='limit',
                                   side=position.direction,
                                   amount=size,
                                   price=float(position.entry),

author: 3ntr0phy

comments.body:
Hello @3ntr0phy,

Actually, `stopLossPrice` and `takeProfitPrice` params are incompatible params, because they're meant to be used when you want your order or behave as a `stopLoss` **or** `takeProfit` orders. 

If you want to attach a takeProfit and stopLoss order to the position being opened, you should use the `stopLoss` and `takeProfit` params.

Example:

```Python
params = {
    'stopLoss': str(float(position.sl)), # stringified number
    'takeProfi': str(float(position.tp)), # stringified number
}
bybit.create_order(...., params = params)
```
Great it works!

body:
### ÿú

Hello and a happy new year to everyone :-),

OS: Windows 10
Programming Language version: Python Spyder 3.9
CCXT version: ccxt-2.4.47

My question is: How to create an stop order/trigger order on deribit?
Unfortunately I can't find any information that can help me. I already checked API documentation from deribit and searched here on github.

I tried different order types. But If I want to place a stop order under entry price and market price the order will be triggered
immediately and position gets closed.

Example:
pos_size = 10
Entry price: 1215 (long)
Market price: 1216

params={'reduce_only': True,
         'close_on_trigger': True}
deribit.create_stop_market_order(symbol, side='sell', amount=pos_size, stopPrice=1200, params=params)

-->
Position will be closed immediately

Hopefully someone can help me, thanks!
author: Nitrix321

comments.body:
Hello @Nitrix321,
Deribit has two types of stop orders, take profit or stop loss orders. Basically, if you want the order to trigger when the price crosses from above (for instance, the price dropped from 70 to 60) you should use the `stopLossPrice` in params, if you want a trigger when the price crosses from above  `takeProfitPrice` is the correct parameter. 

Example take profit order: 
```Python
    params = {
        'takeProfitPrice': 100 # buy orders are allowed when price crosses from below
    }
    create_order = await exchange.create_order(symbol, type, side, amount, price, params)
```

Example stop loss order: 
```Python
    params = {
        'stopLossPrice': 50 # stop loss sell orders are allowed when price crosses from above
    }
    create_order = await exchange.create_order(symbol, type, side, amount, price, params)
```

Hi @carlosmiei , thank u very much again.
I will try it again :-).

title: Asyncio workflow
body:
- Programming Language version: Python 3.10.5
- CCXT version: 2.2.91

If I understand the asyncio functionality correctly , the workflow for this code is as following:
```
import asyncio
import ccxt.pro


async def loop(exchange, symbol):
    while True:
        orderbook = await exchange.fetch_order_book(symbol)
        # code without call exchange method
        if condition:
            await exchange.create_order(symbol, ...)


async def main():
    exchange = ccxt.pro.binance()
    symbols = ['symbol1', 'symbol2', 'symbolN']
    await asyncio.gather(*[loop(exchange, symbol) for symbol in symbols])


asyncio.run(main())
```
1. All loop functions execute code until 'fetch_order_book' call.
2. Execute 'fetch_order_book' and execute code until 'fetch_order_book' if condition not True else until 'create_order'
3. From symbol1 to symbolN in the order, execute 'fetch_order_book' or 'create_order'

Is it right? 
So my question is how can I execute the 'create_order' function immediately after 'fetch_order_book' if condition is True.

The purpose of my question is in case of you have lot of symbol in symbols list. If only the last symbol has condition True, you need to wait all symbol to fetch him orderbook before post your order. I would like to minimize the time between the execution of 'fetch_order_book_ and the execution of the trade.

Thanks you very much for your help.
author: Hadevmin

comments.body:
Hi @Hadevmin ,

Not exactly. So asyncio will run all the loop functions in parallel and independently.
Each loop function will first wait for `fetch_order_book`, check the condition and if true immediately call create_order. And continuously do so.

So this code should meet your needs of executing the 'create_order' function immediately after 'fetch_order_book' if condition is True.

Also for this case I'd recommend using `watch_order_book` which will provide order book updates, instead of having to fetch the full order book.

Please let me know if you have any further questions, if not feel free to close the issue

Hi @pcriadoperez,

I probably made some mistakes in my tests because I was not observing this scenario....
Thanks for your help! And for the method, it is the case! ;)
I use this condition before calling the order book or the account balance.
```
if exchange.has['watchOrderBook']:
   exchange.watch_order_book
   ...
elif exchange.has['fetchOrderBook']:
   exchange.fetch_order_book
   ...
```

title: Can I use the repo to receive tokens to and from different networks?
body:
- OS: Windows 10 PRO
- Programming Language version: Node.js (version 19.2.0)
- CCXT version: 2.2.84

Hi,

I know I can use CCXT to withdraw tokens to any address if they are in ERC20, BEP20, SPL, TRC20 networks.
But I want to know if I can use some wallet, like Exodus which has desktop version, I create a wallet and I have the private key. I can withdraw tokens from my account in exchange to my wallet and can I use CCXT with the private key to send tokens from my wallet address to another my account in another exchange.

For example: 

Let‚Äôs say I setup Exodus wallet for Windows 10, and I have the address with the private key.

If I want to withdraw some USDT from my Binance account via ERC20 network, after I receive the USDT from my Binance account, can I use CCXT with the Exodus wallet private key, after paying the gas fees, send USDT to my Huobipro account via BEP20 network?

I think receiving the USDT should work,  as it just a different address as any other exchange address.

Please advise if I can send USDT from wallet address with private key to another account in different exchange.
Thanks,
author: zydjohnHotmail

comments.body:
Hello @zydjohnHotmail, the short answer is no,
CCXT wraps the exchange's API so basically, we're only a middleware that wraps the REST calls you make to the Exchange. So as you said, yes you can use ccxt to ask the exchange X to withdraw the token to Y wallet, but not the other way around but ccxt itself does not interact with the blockchain.
Thanks for your feed back!
@zydjohnHotmail You're welcome! üôÇ

author: abdellah9

comments.body:
Hi @abdellah9 ,
In binance the method `fetch_order` requires a symbol argument.
You can fix this in your code by changing:
 From: `order = exchange.fetch_order(buy_order['orderId'])` To: `order = exchange.fetch_order(buy_order['orderId'], config.SYMBOL)`
 
For now I'll close this issue, but feel free to ask any more questions.

title: qty error for bybit
author: belqit

comments.body:
Hi @belqit 

I think that's the market and precision issue. In bybit, it depends on what market you want to trade, looks like they have same id for spot and swap market pair, eg `BTCUSDT`.

So we used `defaultType` to handle different market. The default type is `swap`, the market you loaded is swap market (the precision for swap is 0.001).

If you want to buy spot, please set `defaultType` to `spot` (precision is 0.000001).

```JS
  const bybit = new ccxt.bybit({
    "apiKey": "",
    "secret": "",
    'options': {
      'defaultType': 'spot'
    }
  })
```

Let me know if you have other questions.

```
ccxt.base.errors.BadSymbol: bybit does not have market symbol BTCPERP
```

This is header
```
bybit = ccxt.bybit({
"apiKey": "xxxx",
"secret": "xxxx",
"options": {'defaultType': 'future'}
})
print(bybit.fetchMarkets())
```

Is bybit USDC perp contracts have some specific type for it?

ps. Sorry for trouble
author: croissantty

comments.body:
Hello @croissantty, Bybit has conflicting ids between USDT settle derivatives and the USDC one (BTC-PERP), so I would recommend using the unified symbol, in this case `BTC/USD:USDC`

Example:
```Python
ticker = await exchange.fetch_ticker('BTC/USD:USDC')
```

Regarding the balance, by default  will return the usdt based wallet balance, to change it, you have two options
- settle the `defaultSettle` option as `USDC` `exchange.options['defaultSettle`] = 'USDC' `
- add `settle` to `params` 

Example:

```Python
params = {
    'settle': 'USDC'
}
balance = await exchange.fetch_balance(params)
```

Very thank you @carlosmiei, with your help now I can access balance and symbol. but look like `fetchMyTrades()` is not working with this exchange or I'm missing something?

```
ccxt.base.errors.NotSupported: bybit fetchMyTrades() is not supported for market BTC/USD:USDC
```

> is not supported for market

You are right, seems the current implementation doesn't have any endpoint to access it, so it seems bybit is lacking that endpoint, we can't do anything in such case (if anyone finds out that that bybit added/supports it now and we have a missing implementation, let us know)

title: How to work with Futures for other exchanges except Binance and KuCoin?
body:
Hi,
Based on the list of available exchanges, it can be seen that Binance and KuCoin have a separate id for working with Futures. But what about other exchanges? For example, HitBTC also has futures in its API.

Work with them is not implemented or is there a trick here?

Thanks
author: voitovych-com

comments.body:
Hi @rvoitovich,
Some exchanges have seperate id's when they have specific api keys, or different urls. But for most exchanges ccxt uses the same id for different markets types. You can check if an exchange supports futures by checking  `if (exchange.has['future'] === true` or `if (exchange.has['swap'] === true)` for perpetuals.
In the case of hitBTC, the exchange id hitBTC3 supports swaps but not futures.

I'll close this issue for now but feel free to comment or open a new issue if you have any further questions

title: Wait longer before raising Request timeout Error.
body:
When fetching data from Binance, it happens (rarely) that my internet wi-fi goes slow, for few minutes. How to tell to ccxt to "wait longer" before interrupting the code?


```python
import ccxt
import pandas as pd
from datetime import datetime
import time

binance = ccxt.binance()

def getData():
    usdt_1m = binance.fetch_ohlcv("BTC/USDT",'1m',limit=1)
    usdt_1m = pd.DataFrame(usdt_1m)

    t = int(usdt_1m.iloc[0,0]/1000)
    t = datetime.fromtimestamp(t)
    usdt_1m.iloc[0,0] = t
    return usdt_1m

While True:
    getData()
```

Thank you
author: riemanncode

comments.body:
Hi @riemanncode 

The default timeout is 10 seconds, you can update value when initialize exchange object.

```python
binance = ccxt.binance({
  'timeout': 20000
})
```

title: How to implement fetchCurrency?
author: zydjohnHotmail

comments.body:
Hi @zydjohnHotmail 

There are `currency(code)` and `safeCurrency(currencyId, currency` in Exchange class, you can use them to get currency.

@zydjohnHotmail 

Here's an example of how you would use the currency method to get the info for a currency. You need to provide your `apiKey` and `secret` to binance, or else you will get different results

```JavaScript
const ccxt = require('ccxt');
const keys = require('./keys.local.json');

(async function () {
    const exchange = new ccxt.binance({
        ...keys.binance,
        'options': {
            'fetchCurrencies': true,
        },
    });
    await exchange.loadMarkets ();
    const currency = exchange.currency ('USDT');
    console.log (currency);
})();
```

title: Computational performance in Node.js too slow
author: BongSuCHOI

comments.body:
Hi @BongSuCHOI , 

So Node.js is actually faster than python, as node.js is a compiled language while python is interpreted. However the difference in performance is really minimal and don't think this is your issue. To reduce complexity I would recommend sticking to the language you feel more comfortable in.

The slowest part in your code will be the calls to the server much more than the calculations. Here Websockets can definitely help and they are available through ccxt in javascript, php and python. I would to try that first.

I'll close this issue for now, but feel free to re-open or ask more questions if they come up.

@pcriadoperez 
> The slowest part in your code will be the calls to the server


The answer was late.
thank you! I think I found the keyword of performance improvement refactoring after hearing your answer.

Looking closely at my code, asynchronous functions such as the fetchOHLCV() function were being called multiple times.

If the problem still occurs after improving the performance, I will open the problem again, thank you!

for spot, i am just using $exchange->create_market_buy_order
author: ngdekhai

comments.body:
Hello @ngdekhai, You can activate the `last_response_headers` option to access that information, example:

```Python
exchange = ccxt.binance({
    # 'apiKey': 'YOUR_API_KEY',
    # 'secret': 'YOUR_SECRET_KEY',
    'last_response_headers': True,
})

markets = await exchange.load_markets()

order = await exchange.create_order(your params here)
## Get headers from the last call
headers = exchange.last_response_headers
print(headers)
```
@carlosmiei thanks for the help

title: Avoid partial execution of a sell order.
body: How to avoid partial execution for a sell market order for FTX exchange ? I would like to cancel the order if the order amount is not enough for selling.
author: YuriyTigiev

comments.body:
Hi @YuriyTigiev 

I think you're asking for Fill-or-Kill order (FOK) order, unfortunately I didn't see this kind of order in FTX.
Any idea for  a workaround ?

> Any idea for a workaround ?

If exchange doesn't support it natively (which is the only guaranteed way) then there is no workaround we might offer. all what I can say is to check orderbook before submitting the order, and if you see your amount is fillable without your price diapason, then you should submit `ioc` (immediate-or-cancel) order. however, it still doesn't guarantee that your full amount will be executed, because in the second before your order reaches the exchange, the orderbook might have changed more than you expect. What I can advise is to reach out to FTX api support and bother them to add the needed functionality. maybe they listen to customers ever (low chances from my experience, but try).

title: It is possible to serialise FTX or Binance object to Json ?
body:
- OS: MacOS
- Programming Language version: Python 3.9
- CCXT version: 1.92.87


I'm asking this question because I have a massive list of Customers with their respective credentials. I'm trying to make the application more robust by saving each Customer on Redis. But I'm having problem saving the FTX or Binance objects on Redis.

This is my object:
```
from redis_om import JsonModel
from ccxt.ftx import ftx
class Exchange(JsonModel):
    exchange: ftx
```

This is how I'm building each connection:

```
import ccxt

def exchange_connection(api_key, api_secret_key, exchange, sub_account):
    if exchange == "FTX":
        client = ccxt.ftx({
            'apiKey': api_key,
            'secret': api_secret_key,
            'headers': {
                'FTX-SUBACCOUNT': sub_account,
            }
        })
        
    return client
```

And this is the for cycle where I'm saving each customer on Redis:

```

for user in tqdm(users['users']):
        exchange_object = exchange_connection(user['api_key'], user['api_secret_key'], user['exchange'], user['sub_account'])
        exchange = Exchange(exchange=exchange_object)
        exchange.save()

```

However, it is giving me the error -> TypeError: Object of type 'ftx' is not JSON serializable

Is it possible to serialize the FTX object somehow to JSON?

Thank you.
author: filipegalo

comments.body:
Hi @filipegalo 

There is `describe()` function to get basic configuration of the exchange (but without user configuration), eg `exchange.describe()`. To encode user configuration (apiKey or some other credentials), I think you can encode as json and save to Redis in your code and initiate next time.

```
import json

...

Imagine that I have 1000 Users with their respective API_KEY and API_SECRET_KEY, it takes a lot of time to build the exchange object with user configurations for all those users. title: ‚Äé
author: wwalterr

comments.body:
In general : 
Gross profit = Revenue - Cost
Net Profit = Gross profit - Fees

In this case : 
Revenue = Sell cost = 8.44412 which is also equal to Filled * Price = 0.0004 * 21110.3 = 8.44412
Cost = Buy cost = 8.43596 which is also equal to Filled * Price = 0.0004 * 21089.9 = 8.43596
Gross profit  = 8.44412 - 8.43596 = 0.00816
Fees = Sell Fees + Buy Fees = Sell fee.cost + Buy fee.cost = 0.00844412 + 0.00843596 = 0.01688008
Net Profit = 0.00816 -  0.01688008 = -0.00872008

In conclusion, excluding the fees you are profitable on this trade, but all together, you are actually losing money.

Hello @pier0074 

I think your math is on point. As a small optimization, I would suggest using the cost field to do it so that you don't need to calculate it manually

Hello @carlosmiei 

This is what I firstly used.
When I mentioned "which is also equal to", I was just pointing out where the cost field comes from.

```
import os
import sys
import csv


root = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))
sys.path.append(root + '/python')

import ccxt  # noqa: E402



def retry_fetch_ohlcv(exchange, max_retries, symbol, timeframe, since, limit):
    num_retries = 0
    try:
        num_retries += 1
        ohlcv = exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol, timeframe, since, limit)
        # print('Fetched', len(ohlcv), symbol, 'candles from', exchange.iso8601 (ohlcv[0][0]), 'to', exchange.iso8601 (ohlcv[-1][0]))
        return ohlcv
    except Exception:
        if num_retries > max_retries:
            raise  # Exception('Failed to fetch', timeframe, symbol, 'OHLCV in', max_retries, 'attempts')


def scrape_ohlcv(exchange, max_retries, symbol, timeframe, since, limit):
    timeframe_duration_in_seconds = exchange.parse_timeframe(timeframe)
    timeframe_duration_in_ms = timeframe_duration_in_seconds * 1000
    timedelta = limit * timeframe_duration_in_ms
    now = exchange.milliseconds()
    all_ohlcv = []
    fetch_since = since
    while fetch_since < now:
        ohlcv = retry_fetch_ohlcv(exchange, max_retries, symbol, timeframe, fetch_since, limit)
        fetch_since = (ohlcv[-1][0] + 1) if len(ohlcv) else (fetch_since + timedelta)
        all_ohlcv = all_ohlcv + ohlcv
        if len(all_ohlcv):
            print(len(all_ohlcv), 'candles in total from', exchange.iso8601(all_ohlcv[0][0]), 'to', exchange.iso8601(all_ohlcv[-1][0]))
        else:
            print(len(all_ohlcv), 'candles in total from', exchange.iso8601(fetch_since))
    return exchange.filter_by_since_limit(all_ohlcv, since, None, key=0)


def write_to_csv(filename, data):
    with open(filename, mode='w') as output_file:
        csv_writer = csv.writer(output_file, delimiter=',', quotechar='"', quoting=csv.QUOTE_MINIMAL)
        csv_writer.writerows(data)


def scrape_candles_to_csv(filename, exchange_id, max_retries, symbol, timeframe, since, limit):
    # instantiate the exchange by id
    exchange = getattr(ccxt, exchange_id)()
    # convert since from string to milliseconds integer if needed
    if isinstance(since, str):
        since = exchange.parse8601(since)
    # preload all markets from the exchange
    exchange.load_markets()
    # fetch all candles
    ohlcv = scrape_ohlcv(exchange, max_retries, symbol, timeframe, since, limit)
    # save them to csv file
    write_to_csv(filename, ohlcv)
    print('Saved', len(ohlcv), 'candles from', exchange.iso8601(ohlcv[0][0]), 'to', exchange.iso8601(ohlcv[-1][0]), 'to', filename)


scrape_candles_to_csv('ftx1h.csv', 'ftx', 3, 'BTC-PERP', '1h', '2022-08-14T00:00:00Z', 1000)
```

title: Phemex `fetch_positions` does not support phemex official symbol
body:
Phemex `fetch_positions` does not support phemex official symbol

## versions
* OS: Debian 11
* Programming Language version: python 3.8.12
* CCXT version: 1.91.68

## code to reproduce

### setup
```
import ccxt

ccxt_exchange = ccxt.phemex({
    'apiKey': ...,
    'secret': ...,
})
```

### fetch_positions does not support uXXXUSD format
```
ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['uBTCUSD']) # => returns `[]`
ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['BTC/USD:USD']) # => returns position structured response
```

### fetch_positions does not support neither inverse formats
```
ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['BTCUSD']) # => returns `[]`
ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['BTC/USD:BTC']) # => returns `[]`
```
author: takami-ml

comments.body:
Hello @takami-ml 

> ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['uBTCUSD']) # => returns `[]`
> ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['BTC/USD:USD']) # => returns position structured response

Can you double-check this? I've just tested and worked fine with both formats, unified and exchange-specific.


> fetch_positions does not support neither inverse formats
> ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['BTCUSD']) # => returns `[]`
> ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['BTC/USD:BTC']) # => returns `[]`

By default will try to load "linear contracts" to fetch inverse contracts (BTC settled in this case), please provide the settle currency as `code` inside params.

Something like this:
```Python
ccxt_exchange.fetch_positions(symbols=['BTC/USD:BTC'], {'code':'BTC'})
```

@carlosmiei 

Thank you for the information.

> Can you double-check this? I've just tested and worked fine with both formats, unified and exchange-specific.

I'm sorry,  this one was my mistake. (I just had an inverse position, not linear.)
I confirmed it worked as expected.

> By default will try to load "linear contracts" to fetch inverse contracts (BTC settled in this case), please provide the settle currency as code inside params.

When I set `code` to BTC, it worked.
I did not understand the `defaultSubType` option and `code` params. Thanks for the information.

In conclusion, in both cases, there was no problem. I am very sorry to have used your time!
@takami-ml no problem at all, I'll close this issue then, let us know if anything! üôÇ

comments.body: Hello @naokitte, yes our base32 operations seem to be malfunctioning, we will analyze it asap. Thanks for reporting it

> 
Yes, I'll be waiting for the problem to be solved..

Hello @naokitte 

I'm sorry, I ended up confusing myself and gave a wrong answer. Our docs in this subject aren't great either, but we will improve it soon.

Basically, the `twofa` option expects to get the 2fa key (the code encoded inside the QR code)  so that we can generate the six digits OTP and inject it in the request automatically, so by providing it, you don't even have to invoke .oath() manually.

Example:

```Python
exchange = ccxt.ftx({
    'enableRateLimit': True,
    'apiKey': 'API_KEY',
    'secret':  'SECRET',
    'twofa': 'NXKANJQ4FKDAEHG5' # your 2fa secret here
})

code = 'XRP'
amount = 40
address = 'rawrrwweretrr23423424234342tttttttWA'
tag = 423743288
  
result = exchange.withdraw (code, amount, address, tag) # <- OTP will be injected automatically here. You don't need to add it.
```

Alternatively, you can manually provide the OTP on each request, and by doing that, you don't need to provide tour 2fa secret upon instantiating the exchange.

Example

```Python
exchange = ccxt.ftx({
    'enableRateLimit': True,
    'apiKey': 'API_KEY',
    'secret':  'SECRET',
}) # you don't need to provide any 2fa key here

code = 'XRP'
amount = 40
address = 'rawrrwweretrr23423424234342tttttttWA'
tag = 423743288
params = {
    'code': '123456' # injecting your 2fa OTP manually in the request
}
result = exchange.withdraw (code, amount, address, tag, params) 
```

Please let us know if things are a little clearer now or if you need any further clarification!

> 

Hi, Thanks. I solved the problem.
My solution was to eliminate 2FA
I set the setting to turn off 2FA when withdrawl.
Then the withdrawal Python code worked.
and In the 'params' code, I just put in the 'password' : 'blahblahblah'

Anyway, I solved the problem.
"Turn off the 2FA function." 
Other than this, there was an error in the other way I tried.

Thank you
Thank you @carlosmiei ..This issue clarifies authentication.

title: upbit createDepositAddress Error
body:
OS:Windows 10
Programming Language version:Python
CCXT version:1.90.66
Exchange: Upbit
Method: createDepositAddress


AddressPending: upbit is generating BTC deposit address, call fetchDepositAddress or createDepositAddress one more time later to retrieve the generated address


I'd like to know why the code exits with that message when generating an address.

After the code ends, I can check in Upbit that the address has been created
But I can't check it when I create it in python

I couldn't find it after searching after #6452 for this problem.
I'm a beginner in programming, so I don't know if it's a bug or my skill problem.
author: newbienoobnoob

comments.body:
@newbienoobnoob Hello, so when you call `createDepositAdress` there are two things that might happen:
- First, the exchange immediately responds with an address, and you're ready to go
- Second, the exchange warns that it will create an address, but since this is an asynchronous process it can't return it right now, you have to wait a few seconds and request it again.

You can do simple polling until the address is ready, for example:

```Python
    address = None
    while True:
        try:
            address = await exchange.create_deposit_address("BTC")
            break
        except ccxt.AddressPending as e:
            print("Address not ready yet, will wait and try again")
            await exchange.sleep(1000) # sleeps 1 second before trying again
```
Thank you it was a great hint

CCXT version: 1.91.39

```
def get_withdrawal_fees(
        exchange_name: str, path_optimizer, trading_size: int = 1000
) -> dict:
    """
    function to get the withdrawal fees of each exchange through ccxt
    will also calculate the withdrawal fee percentage based on an approximate trading size
    """
    withdrawal_fee = {}
    exchange_instance: ccxt.Exchange = path_optimizer.exchanges[exchange_name]
    currencies: dict = exchange_instance.currencies
    if exchange_instance.has["fetchTickers"]:
        tickers: dict[dict] = exchange_instance.fetch_tickers()
    else:
        raise ccxt.ExchangeError(
            f"{exchange_name} does not support the fetchTickers method"
        )

    coin_name: str
    coin_value: dict
    for coin_name, coin_value in currencies.items():
        coin_fee = int(0) if coin_value["fee"] == 0.0 else coin_value["fee"]
        fee_in_usd = coin_fee * tickers.get(f"{coin_name}/USDT", {}).get("bid", 0)
        withdrawal_fee[coin_name] = {
            "usd_fee": fee_in_usd,
            "usd_rate": fee_in_usd / trading_size,

author: ar3sla

comments.body:
Hello @ar3sla you're mixing up spot and swap market ids.

If you want to place an order for the linear ETH/USDT swap you should be using `ETH-USDT-SWAP` as an argument for `createMarketBuyOrder` instead of `ETH-USDT`, the latter represents the spot symbol.

hi @carlosmiei, thanks for your answer
but when i change it to ETH-USDT-SWAP with this code:
okex = ccxt.okx({
    'apiKey': config.API_KEY,
    'secret': config.API_SECRET,
    'password' : config.API_PASS,
    'options':{
        'defaultType' : 'swap'
        },

})
okex.set_sandbox_mode(True)

params1 = {
    "instId":"ETH-USDT-SWAP",
    "tdMode":"isolated",
    "side":"buy",
    'posSide':"SWAP",
    "ordType":"market",
    "sz":"6"
}
order1 = okex.create_market_buy_order('ETH-USDT-SWAP' , 6 , params=params1)
print(order1)

it shows me this error :
ccxt.base.errors.BadRequest: okx {"code":"1","data":[{"clOrdId":"e847386590ce4dBC2ffbe9c12cb175e0","ordId":"","sCode":"51000","sMsg":"Parameter posSide  error ","tag":""}],"msg":"Operation failed."}



and if i use ETH-USDT in this code :
okex = ccxt.okx({
    'apiKey': config.API_KEY,
    'secret': config.API_SECRET,
    'password' : config.API_PASS,


})
okex.set_sandbox_mode(True)


order1 = okex.create_market_buy_order('ETH-USDT' , 6 )
print(order1)

it shows me this error :

ccxt.base.errors.InsufficientFunds: okx {"code":"1","data":[{"clOrdId":"e847386590ce4dBCb25a7bde230285b0","ordId":"","sCode":"51008","sMsg":"Order placement failed due to insufficient balance ","tag":""}],"msg":"Operation failed."}

Hello @ar3sla,

> order1 = okex.create_market_buy_order('ETH-USDT' , 6 )
> print(order1)

this is not what you want, as said earlier 'ETH-USDT' is a spot symbol, so you're saying "I want to buy 6 ETH with USDT"

> order1 = okex.create_market_buy_order('ETH-USDT-SWAP' , 6 , params=params1)
> print(order1)

You're almost there, you're just missing the `postSide` parameter required by OKX.

Something like this:
```Python

params1 = {
    "marginMode":"isolated", # or cross
    "posSide":"long", # long or short depending on your intent
}
symbol = "ETH-USDT-SWAP"
amount = 6 # number of contracts
order1 = okex.create_market_buy_order(symbol , amount , params=params1)
print(order1)
```

thanks a lot @carlosmiei
the posside solved my problem.
I'm really thankful

async def main():

author: ysonitis5

comments.body:
Hello @ysonitis5,

You're trying to access a non-existent field in the raw response, which is why it's crashing.

To fix it you can either search for the unified `maintenanceMargin` field, like this:
```Python
positions = kucoin.fetch_positions(symbols=[symbol], params=params)
maintenance_margin = positions[0]['maintenanceMargin'] # the advisable way to get it
```
or access the correct raw value inside `info`, 

```Python
positions = kucoin.fetch_positions(symbols=[symbol], params=params)
maintenance_margin = positions[0]['info']['posMaint'] # not recommended because APIs are always changing
```

@ysonitis5  You're welcome, since the problem seems resolved I will close the issue, let us know if anything!

title: Huobi Spot sell orders price and average value always equals to 1
body:
We've noticed that on Huobi Spot market `sell` orders `price` and `average` values always equals to 1, but in `buy` orders results prices are correct. 
Looks like it is because of on `ccxt` side `price` = `average` = `cost` / `amount`, 
where `cost` value contains traded currency amount and because of that prices for `sell` orders equals to 1.
Right now we use next formula that helps avoid incorrect prices values:

```
if (ccxtResult['side'] === 'sell') {
      ccxtResult['average'] = ccxtResult.info['field-cash-amount'] / ccxtResult.info['field-amount'];
      ccxtResult['price'] = ccxtResult.info['field-cash-amount'] / ccxtResult.info['field-amount'];
}
```

title: How to judge whether the stop-loss order is triggered?
body:
When the price falls, the stop-loss order may be triggered. How to judge whether the stop-loss order is triggered?
the code as follows:
```
import ccxt
import time
from pprint import pprint
ftx = ccxt.ftx({
    'apiKey': 'my_apikey',
    'secret': 'my_secret',
})

print("CCXT Version:", ccxt.__version__)
markets = ftx.load_markets()

symbol = 'BTC/USD:USD'
ftx.load_markets()
market = ftx.market(symbol)
btc_maket_price = float(market['info']['price'])
btc_amount = 20 / btc_maket_price
create_order = ftx.create_order(symbol, 'market', 'buy', btc_amount)

type = 'stop'
side = 'sell'
price = None
drop_btc_price = btc_maket_price - btc_maket_price * 0.02
params = {
    'stopPrice': drop_btc_price,
}
order2 = ftx.create_order(symbol, type, side, btc_amount, price, params)

```
author: qwe231cvb

comments.body:
Hello @qwe231cvb,

There are two approaches here you can follow:

**First**, periodically poll the exchange using REST to check the order state.

Example:

```Python

order = ftx.create_order(symbol, 'market', 'buy', btc_amount)
order_id = order['id']

# every 5 seconds will fetch the order info
while True
    order_info = ftx.fetch_order(id)
    if order_info['status'] !== 'open':
         print('order triggered')
         break
    time.sleep(5) 
```

The first approach is easy to implement but less efficient and more resource-demanding. Alternatively, you could use the WebSockets version of ccx, ccxt.pro and subscribe to order updates to get that information in real-time. 

Something like this:

```Python

import asyncio
import ccxtpro

ftx = ccxtpro.ftx({
    'apiKey': 'my_apikey',
    'secret': 'my_secret',
})

created_id = XXX
order_symbol = 'BTC/USDT'

async def loop(exchange, symbol):
    while True:
        orders = await exchange.watch_orders(symbol)
        for order in orders:
            if order['id'] === created_id and order['status'] !== 'open':
                print('Order was triggered!')

async def main():
    await loop(ftx, order_symbol)
    await exchange.close()


if __name__ == '__main__':
    asyncio.run(main())
```

The latter approach is the most effective one but requires some knowledge of Websockets and asynchronous programming.

title: Consistent way to get filled market orders
body:
- Programming Language version: python
- CCXT version: '1.77.5'

I am trying to create a dca bot that can work on various exchanges. I have trouble retrieving the results (price, amount, cost, filled ...) of market orders in a way that works consistently regardless of the exchange you choose.

With Binance, I only need to look at the results of: 
```
order = self.exchange.create_order(symbol, type_order, side, amount, price)
```
But I realized that for other exchanges, as FTX, that doesn't work. So, I have to fetch_order using the order ID: 
```
order = self.exchange.create_order(symbol, type_order, side, amount, price)
order = self.exchange.fetch_order(order['id'], symbol)
```
I thought the above would resolve any problem, since it does work with FTX. Surprisingly, the above doesn't work with Kucoin. Even after fetch_order, the fields are null/zero and the "status" is still "open". 

I thought maybe I need to give some time to the exchange to fill the order, so I wrote the following:
```
order = self.exchange.create_order(symbol, type_order, side, amount, price)
# for some exchanges (as FTX) the order must be retrieved to be updated
waiting_time = 0.25; total_time = 0
while order['status'] == 'open':
        if total_time > 1:
               raise Exception("The exchange did not return a closed order")
        time.sleep(waiting_time)  # let's give the exchange some time to fill the order
        order = self.exchange.fetch_order(order['id'], symbol)
        total_time += waiting_time
```
 But, it's even worse now. Now, the "status" field is null too. 

How can I collect the result of a market order in a reliable way (i.e., that works on every (or almost all) exchanges)? Thank you!
author: CodingCryptoTrading

comments.body:
Some exchanges won't return all the fields, so CCXT fills in the fields that are available, and sets the field to None otherwise. 

You can look inside the value for `info` to see if there's other information that you might find useful, and if you notice a value in info that could be used for one of the fields that's set to None, then we can update it.

It's also possible that the exchange api has posted a new api endpoint that we haven't seen yet, so if you notice something on the exchange api, we could update that too

> Even after fetch_order, the fields are null/zero and the "status" is still "open".

What should it be? Why would calling `fetch_order` change the status of the order to other than open?

I was referring to very basic fields of a **market order**, such as  *price*, *amount*, *cost* and *filled*. 

Actually, calling `fetch_order` after a `create_order` does populate the missing fields in FTX. It also does work for kucoin, but it seems that I have to wait some time to ensure that the market order is filled and the position is closed. 
Indeed, I found out that the code I posted above works if I replace the while condition from 
```while order['status'] == 'open':``` 
 to:
```while order['status'] != 'closed'):```

I'm just wondering if this strategy will work for every exchange. Or perhaps there is a more reliable strategy, such as fetching trades?

Thanks

> I was referring to very basic fields of a **market order**, such as  *price*, *amount*, *cost* and *filled*. 

No matter how basic they are, if the exchange doesn't return them, then we can't provide them in the response. You can double check the info parameter in the response and if the information isn't in there then we can't provide it.

> I'm just wondering if this strategy will work for every exchange. Or perhaps there is a more reliable strategy, such as fetching trades?

`fetchMyTrades`, `fetchOrder`, `fetchClosedOrders` are the only kinds of methods I can think of that would work for what you want
Ok, thanks

title: How can I sell all of a specific token in my account?
body:
- OS: OSX
- Programming Language version: python3.9
- CCXT version: latest

I want to sell all of the AXS (a smaller-cap token) in my FTX account.
My FTX account has 130.8238727 AXS  in it.
When I run ftx.fetchBalance(), I can pull that number, and I save it as position_info['spot_held'].

I then try to sell it all on the spot market.

```
submission = ftx.create_order ("AXS/USD", 'market', side='sell', amount=abs(position_info["spot_held"]),  params={"reduceOnly": True})
```

But I am then greeted with an Insufficient Funds error:

```
ccxt.base.errors.InsufficientFunds: ftx {"success":false,"error":"Not enough balances"}
```

Why can't I sell all of the tokens in my account, and if I can't sell them all, how can I pass an argument to sell as many as allowed?

Thank you
author: shep-analytics

comments.body:
Hello @shep-analytics 

The code you are using works fine with me.
I assume the error comes from the fact that you are trying to sell more than what you have.

Could you please share the result of ftx.fetchBalance() ?

Note that there are 2 balances for a coin: free and total. 
You can only sell the free balance which is equal to total - all pending orders that you have placed.
So if you have current pending orders for AXS, they are not considered free anymore and cannot be sold.
You can either cancel all orders on AXS and execute your code again, or sell only the free balance of AXS.

Hope it helps.

title: Is it possible to fetch history data of a delisted pair like LUNABTC?
body:
The main question was is it possible to fetch data history of LUNABTC, but I asked it in more general format. As we know Binance de-listed `LUNA` and re-added. When this is done `LUNABTC` pair is removed and its history also wiped out. 

I was wondering somehow is it possible to fetch `LUNABTC` pairs history price data even it is de-listed on Binance?
author: avatar-lavventura

comments.body:
You can fetch LUNA/BTC history with CCXT:

```Python
import ccxt

print('CCXT Version:', ccxt.__version__)

def table(values):
    first = values[0]
    keys = list(first.keys()) if isinstance(first, dict) else range(0, len(first))
    widths = [max([len(str(v[k])) for v in values]) for k in keys]
    string = ' | '.join(['{:<' + str(w) + '}' for w in widths])
    return "\n".join([string.format(*[str(v[k]) for k in keys]) for v in values])


exchange = ccxt.binance()
markets = exchange.load_markets()
symbol = 'LUNA/BTC'
since = exchange.parse8601('2021-01-01T00:00:00Z')
ohlcvs = exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol, '1h', since)
print(table([[exchange.iso8601(int(o[0]))] + o[1:] for o in ohlcvs]))
```
It fetches only 21 days is it normal like: from `2021-01-01T00:00:00.000Z` to `2021-01-21T19:00:00.000Z`?

title: Implementation for Bittrex of fetch_currencies breaks when Bittrex does not return a countable.
author: iwanluijks

comments.body:
> The $response however might not be a countable value, and might be for example null

Can you please paste the code you use to reproduce it or your complete verbose output with a null-response? It should have been intercepted in the error handler.

The code in the issue is actually the code...

We call `$bittrex->fetch_currencies([]);`, thus `fetch_currencies` with an empty array for the `$params` argument. The first line in `fetch_currencies` is:
```
$response = $this->publicGetCurrencies ($params);
```

That results in `$response` being `null` sometimes (not always, sometimes). And `$response` is used a few lines below that within `fetch_currencies` as:
```
for ($i = 0; $i < count($response); $i++) {
```

which thus fails as `$response` is not countable...
bittrex is closed

title: Auto retry call
body:
Hello, 

Will ccxt  add support auto retry call a function for case with network issue? 
For example by default retry parameters could be 
1) retry_attempts = 0
2) retry_period = 2 sec
author: YuriyTigiev

comments.body: I had the similar approach, but question is - could we implement this code on the library level?
What is equivalent of code for  python for the string - `return await exchange[method] (... args)`
Does current version of library support auto reconnect?

@YuriyTigiev CCXT Pro does auto-reconnection with the WS API, and CCXT is a RESTful API. There is no such thing as a connection in terms of CCXT, just HTTPS requests and responses over a TCP/IP, all connection-related things are abstracted away, but can be configured and overrided.
It's means I don't need to use previous code if I use ccxt.pro. Correct ?

> It's means I don't need to use previous code if I use ccxt.pro. Correct ?

Nope, the above code is not a part of CCXT or CCXT Pro. The code above does not handle reconnections, it just handles a number of attempts/retries on HTTPS failures, if any. Don't confuse retry-calls over HTTPS with reconnections over WS, they're different things. The code above does not involve any type of connection at all. CCXT Pro is using WS connections, but that is not related to the above code either.
when approximately ccxt.pro will be free to use ?
@YuriyTigiev in July 2022.

title: Fill or Kill limit order doesn't fill although the orderbook shows it should
body:
- OS: Windows 10
- Programming Language version: Python 3.10.2
- CCXT version: 1.82.94

Hi! This is my first issue submitting, so I'll try to do my best.
This is a question, not an issue :D (I dont know if I have to label it or the team does it)

My script has 2 clear phases:
 - Checks orderbook at exchange 1
 - Puts a limit order based on that orderbook in exchange 2 with time in force: fill or kill

Aswell, I monitorize the price differences between both exchanges all the time.

There is no error code, simply I don't understand why sometimes it executes correctly but not always, it is not consistent.

Here is the code where I check the orderbook and place an order based on that.

```
sask = 9999999999
sbid = 9999999999
params = {
    'timeInForce': 'FOK',
}

orderbook = exchange_1.fetch_order_book(symbol_1)
sbid = orderbook['bids'][0][0] if len (orderbook['bids']) > 0 else None
sask = orderbook['asks'][0][0] if len (orderbook['asks']) > 0 else None

if sbid != 9999999999 and sask != 9999999999:
    askTarget = sask + (sask * profit)
    bidTarget = sbid - (sbid * profit)

    try:
        if direction == "sold":
            cqty = min(((qtyUSD/bidTarget)*0.997), qtyCoin)
            buy_order = exchange_2.create_limit_buy_order(symbol_2, cqty, bidTarget, params)
            sell_order = None
        elif direction == "bought":
            cqty = min(((qtyUSD/askTarget)*0.997), qtyCoin)
            sell_order = exchange_2.create_limit_sell_order(symbol_2, cqty, askTarget, params)
            buy_order = None
```

I checked and monitorized the mayority of the possible problems and I discarded some issues.

 - The order is set always at the price I want correctly.
 - The amount is correct always.
 - I manage the exceptions but I deleted them from the code snippet in order to be easier to read and understand it, so it is not exception management issue.
 
I'm working with kucoin, Binance, Ftx, bybit etc.

I noticed this hapens trading in spot, but when I apply the same code in futures, it executes perfectly, always.

So I monitorized the script printing the variables in the phases, and this is an example of one of the failed ones:

```
---------------  binance  -  kucoin  -  AGLD/USDT  -  AGLD/USDT  -  0.155  ---------------
(All from Kucoin): bid target:  0.5761 ask:  0.585 ask target:  0.5809 bid:  0.5821
(Actual placed order): Sell Order price:  0.5808989999999999
(*)Margin:  0.2067
(first layer of orderbook [price, amount]): [0.5821, 119.0119]
```
* Margin: Price difference between exchange 1 and echange 2, calculated like that: ((bid/askTarget)-1). Being both from kucoin. (askTarget is calculated with binance price as seen in the code snippet). So when margin > 0 the bid is actually bigger than my sell price, so it should fill.


In this case, I'm putting a sell order at kucoin at my target which is: ask target:  0.5809.
So as you can see the sell order sets perfectly at price: 0.5808989999999999
And the bid in that moment is 0.5821, which is bigger.

I though that a possible reason why it doesn't fill, could be that, as I use Time in Force: 'FOK', the amount of the first bid could be smaller than my order, but as you can see at the orderbook stamp, [0.5821, 119.0119], there is 119 coins at price 0.5821, and my order amount was 35.

I use Threading and execute this every 0.35 seconds. So it could be that too.

So I don't really know why it doesn't fill. Any idea?

There is another cases where the order is filled when the margin is between -1 and -0.6, which does not make much sense, as the bid should be much lower than my sell order.

Thanks in advance, and I'm sorry if there is gramatical errors (as I'm not native speaker) or something I did bad. This is my first issue submit, so feel free to correct me :D
author: echograph

comments.body:
Hi, I've been testing more with this issue, and I have some conclusions. So, I've tested a lot more, and the program executes when margins suggest it shouldn't, and it does not execute when it should. That makes me think that fill or kill limit orders doesn't match the orderbook orders but the market orders instead. That would explain why the orders fill when my orders are in a price where it shouldn't fill (a 'FoK' limit buy order at any price shouldn't fill if there are more buy orders above).

Could this be possible?
Do you have any idea what's happening?

If you need more test cases or more code or explanations just tell me :D

Thanks!

I will add my thoughts:
1) orderbooks doesn't always reflect the truth (depends on exchange quality). there are many cases when "top-tier" exchanges (to name a few, I've myself met gate.io, mexc, etc) having fake entries in data/orderbook, while there are actually no real orders. also washtrading... So, when you expect that there is `X` amount in orderbook, it might not be in reality.
2) the second thing, which I think it more realistically related to your issue, is that, when you fetch orderbook data, then already i.e. 1-2 seconds might be gone before your next script-decided order reaches exchange server. So, by that time, that orderbook entry might already by taken by someone other trader (don't think that you are the only one who trades arbitrage, and ppl have more strong servers/scripts). So, it might be the problem, which you might not be able to fix
3) also, last note, are you sure the parameter keyname `timeInForce` is accepted on `exchange2`? ensure that.

let us know if you have any further issue with CCXT.

You should refrain from using the implicit API/ internal helper methods whenever possible, if you carefully read CCXT manual you will see that most of the information you might wanna consult is available through our unified methods in a simple and organized way.

exchange = ccxt.gateio({

author: Kinzowa

comments.body: @Kinzowa do you always use fetchOrder in all cases, or do you get those orders from different methods (say, fetchOrder / fetchOrders, or fetchOrder/createOrder, etc) ?

Hi @kroitor , thanks for your answer. Yes I use different methods. When an order is placed with `createOrder` I catch the response and, if the status is still `open` then I periodically check it with `fetchOrder`.

Now I understand, fee and trades are only reported by the exchange with `createOrder` if the order is executed.

If I understand correctly, Binance returns `fee` and `commission` keys when the order takes liquidity (taker), but not if it's a maker.

> Now I understand, fee and trades are only reported by the exchange with `createOrder` if the order is executed.
>
> If I understand correctly, Binance returns `fee` and `commission` keys when the order takes liquidity (taker), but not if it's a maker.

Basically, the fee is a property of a trade, not a property of an order. Most of the exchanges will return those fees with trades from fetchMyTrades. Some exchanges will also return those fees in the orders, but not all of them. That is because a single order can be filled with multiple trades, and then you have to sum up those fees to get the total fee. When the exchange does not specify a total fee on the order, ccxt can calculate it, if the exchange returns the trade information within the order. However, Binance exchange will only return that trade+fee information within createOrder upon placing it. And when you query it later, the trade+fee info is not available from the fetchOrder-endpoint. Hence, you have to fetchMyTrades, filter those trades by the order id and sum up their fees by currency. Hope that answers your question. Feel free to reopen this issue or just ask further questions if any.
