title: How to access the timestamp at which markets were loaded
body:
Is there an easy way to access the time at which markets were last loaded for an exchange instance? It'd be useful to be able to determine this programmatically from the instance data, so we could automatically refresh it after some period (e.g. every 4 hours). However, there's nothing in the `exchange.markets` object.

Is there another way to access this timestamp, or would you consider making it accessible in a property (such as how `.last_http_response` gives you the most recent response)?
author: HartS

comments.body: Also, I can make a PR for this if it's not already exposed somehow, and you'd be interested in adding it

@HartS your PRs are welcome! 

Design-wise, i think we should differentiate (a) the timestamp when the data was loaded from (b) the timestamp when the data was generated and reported by the exchange (if specified in the response from the exchange).

We could probably add timestamp (b) to the market structure, as for the timestamp (a) ‚Äì¬†since that information is generated on the client side, maybe we should keep it in the userland? I mean to get timestamp (a), you would do something like:

```Python
markets = exchange.load_markets()
when_markets_were_loaded = exchange.milliseconds()
```

We're not filling-in the timestamp if it's missing in the other structures since the user can obtain it immediately after the call, which is basically the equivalent of timestamp (a). 

What do you think on the above ?

I was definitely more interested in (I think) `(a)`, because it allows us to do something like, check the timestamp at which market info was last loaded; if older than a certain age, reload markets (allows us to stay in sync with new markets without spamming the exchange).

It's of course possible to do this on the client side as well, but would be really nice to have it in ccxt since that's a more persistent state stored in the client.

I'll also take a look at what exchanges are providing for the response, though, to see how I can reconcile that with potentilaly available exchange-provided information that a user might be interested in

I think I would mark this as `wontfix` as all responses ccxt provides from exchange, is whatever data is provided from exchanges itself. in `fetchMarkets` response we don't have any place where it could be propagated (i am against adding the same value in each market-object, as it doesn't make any sense to add same unimportant timestamp to 1000's markets).
Moreover, `fetchMarkets` is not (should not be!) frequently used method and it's only called once per instantiation, however, if you want to keep track of it and refresh, I see that a perfect fit for userland code. If you want it to load once in several hours, I don't understand, why it wouldnt be best approach to store timestamp on client side (without need to know that timestamp from exchange, as even in worst scenario, the difference at maximum might be several seconds, and  several seconds absolutely play no difference if you are reloading it once in every X hours).

I know it's good that library had shorthands for everything user needs, but this case belongs to userland code.
Let us know if you have any further issue with CCXT.

title: how to get latest orderId by exchange.fetch_orders("BTC/USDT") in Binance
body:
Hi there,
I use exchange.fetch_orders("BTC/USDT") to get all information ( including orderId, status, clientOrderId,.......) 
within a period of time in Binance.
Please advise what is the code if I only want to get the latest orderId for "BTC/USDT". Thanks.

Charles
author: ctu1121

comments.body:
@ctu1121 here is an example in python:

```Python
import ccxt

binance = ccxt.binance ({'apiKey': 'YOUR_API_KEY', 'secret': 'YOUR_SECRET_KEY'})

symbol = 'BTC/USDT'

orders = binance.fetch_orders(symbol)

sorted_orders = sorted(orders, key=lambda x: x['timestamp'])

most_recent_order = sorted_orders[-1]

id_most_recent_order = most_recent_order['id']

print('most recent self sorted order id: {}'.format(id_most_recent_order))

# however you can also just use 
# the last element in the array returned by ccxt
# it is automatically sorted by default 
# where timestamp/datetime is returned by the exchange

most_recent_order = orders[-1]

id_most_recent_order = most_recent_order['id']

print('most recent default ccxt response order id: {}'.format(id_most_recent_order))
```

title: [ccxt.pro] open price does not match last minute close price for build_ohlcvc
body:
I wrote a script to `watch_trades` and calculate the `ohlcv` using `build_ohlcvc(trades)` once the last minute is finished.
But the **open** price does not match the **close** price of the previous minute:

## `pro`: `watch_trades`  + `build_ohlcvc`
```
New DATA added:
            timestamp     open     high      low    close   volume
0 2022-04-06 09:10:00  2.61885  2.63085    2.612  2.62605   7161.0
1 2022-04-06 09:11:00   2.6248  2.64805  2.62425  2.64805  23759.0
2 2022-04-06 09:12:00   2.6495   2.6495  2.63685   2.6375  30576.0
```

## `non-pro`: `fetch_ohlcv`
Using the `ccxt` `non-pro` version and `fetch_ohlcv` gives the following results:
```
            timestamp     open     high      low    close   volume
0  2022-04-06 07:41:00  2.44300  2.45345  2.44210  2.45150  104563.88285
1  2022-04-06 07:42:00  2.45145  2.45160  2.44410  2.44440  102422.49925
2  2022-04-06 07:43:00  2.44440  2.44570  2.43005  2.43705   56166.47170
3  2022-04-06 07:44:00  2.43705  2.43830  2.43290  2.43570   10986.85700
4  2022-04-06 07:45:00  2.43560  2.43970  2.43070  2.43585   50215.61940
```

Is this an issue of the `build_ohlcvc` or something else?
Is there a way to fix it?
author: xarthurx

comments.body:
> Is this an issue of the build_ohlcvc or something else?

This is not an issue, it's by design. The true info is returned in both cases, depending on how you look at it.
If you define the open price as the price of the first trade within that period, then your open price does not have to be the same as the closing price (this is probably more correct financially)
If you define the open price as the closing price of the last candle, then your open price will match the closing price, obviously (this is better-looking on charts)

> Is there a way to fix it?

Yes, you can easily enforce the open = previous close rule in Python like this:

```Python
ohlcv = exchange.build_ohlcvc(trades, '1m')
ohlcv = [ohlcv[0]] + [[ohlcv[i][0], ohlcv[i - 1][4], ohlcv[i][2], ohlcv[i][3], ohlcv[i][4], ohlcv[i][5]] for i in range(1, len(ohlcv))]
```

title: Transfer USDT between spot and futures
body:
- OS: Windows 
- Programming Language version: 3.10
- CCXT version: 1.77.62

```
import time
start = time.time()
exchange.sapi_post_futures_transfer({
    'asset': 'USDT',
    'amount': '10',
    'type': 2,
})
end = time.time()
```
I want to take a long position in the spot market and a short position in the future market. To do that, I have to make a USDT transfer between spot and future wallets. My question is:

Execution time of the above transfer code is around 1 second. Except for USDT transfer between wallets, my entire code, including creating orders, takes milliseconds. Since USDT transfer takes 1 second, is there a risk that the order execution code runs before USDT transfer so the order can not be implemented due to lack of funds? If so, what would be the best solution?

Maybe I should clarify my question
Let's say that I am in full long position and I receive short signal. So I have to close all long positions, transfer USDT to future wallet and open short positions. Transferring USDT takes around 1 second. I wonder if there is a risk that execution order code(opening short positions) runs before money transfer? If it happens there wont be enough funds to open short position.
author: euphrates85

comments.body:
If you're using async ccxt, you would need to `await` the completion of the transfer before making your order, otherwise, you can just use the unified `transfer` method and not worry about it

```
import ccxt
import pprint

print('CCXT Version:', ccxt.__version__)

binance = ccxt.binance()
transfer = binance.transfer(USDT, 0.01, spot, future)
order = binance.createOrder( ... )
pprint(transfer)
pprint(order)
```

Thank you very much.  I am using synchronous code. I was worried that the code would continue to run without waiting for the money to be physically transferred between wallets. But it seems i shouldn't worry about that

title: properly stop ccxtpro from pulling data
body:
I am struggling to understand how to properly stop ccxtpro from pulling data once I have finished by task. I am using the below example from the user manual.

import ccxtpro
exchange = ccxtpro.ftx({'newUpdates': True})
while True:
    trades = await exchange.watch_trades('BTC/USD')
    print(trades)
    await exchange.close()

I tried returning exchange.close() into the console but that does nothing. How do I stop the data stream when I am finished?
author: amarnp85

comments.body:
Hello @amarnp85 ,

I believe the problem relies on the way you're structuring your code. From the snippet you posted I assume you're doing something like this

```Python
import ccxtpro
exchange = ccxtpro.ftx({'newUpdates': True})
while True:
    trades = await exchange.watch_trades('BTC/USD')
    print(trades)
    await exchange.close()
```

So what you're doing is, per each loop iteration you start a connection and close it in the end, so although it was closed will be created again in the next iteration, that is why you're getting data continuously

You should stop the loop before closing it, something like this
```Python
import ccxtpro
exchange = ccxtpro.ftx({'newUpdates': True})
while True:
    trades = await exchange.watch_trades('BTC/USD')
    print(trades)
    isDone = True # your condition that determines if you want to stop
    if isDone:
        break
await exchange.close()
```

Feel free to reopen the issue if you have any other questions

Thank you. Your response made a lot of sense, but when I tried to implement it stopping after a certain time condition was met the loop just continues running.

import ccxtpro
from datetime import datetime, time

```
stop_time = time(13, 00, 00).strftime("%H:%M:%S")
now = datetime.now().time().strftime("%H:%M:%S")

exchange = ccxtpro.ftx({'newUpdates': True})
while True:
    trades = await exchange.watch_trades('BTC/USD')
    print(trades)
    isDone = now >= stop_time
    if isDone:
        break
await exchange.close()
```

Fixed the issue. I had to define 'now' inside the while loop. Duh!

Thanks for the tip @carlosmiei 

```
stop_time = time(13, 15, 00).strftime("%H:%M:%S")

exchange = ccxtpro.ftx({'newUpdates': True})
while True:
    trades = await exchange.watch_trades('BTC/USD')
    now = datetime.now().time().strftime("%H:%M:%S")
    print(trades)
    print(now)
    if now >= stop_time:
        break
await exchange.close()
```

author: dani-s-92

comments.body: What exchange are you using? Some exchanges have the method `editOrder`, but it might not work for stoploss orders on your exchange, you might need to use `cancelOrder` to cancel your stoploss, and then create a new stoploss order

The above answer by @samgermain was probably sufficient in such case (where there were no more details provided). If anyone has any further issues with CCXT, let us know. Also, provide more specific details as mentioned above.

I would just add, that some exchanges might need to add `{stop: true}` in params, to refer the order type to stop-kind orders.

title: Question: precision of assets
body:
Got a question regarding precision of assets.
It's not clear to me if precision of the same asset/currency if always the same all exchange markets. Or can it be different?
Can I use precision from Currency or should I always use precision from Market (base or quote depending where my currency is). 

For example, is it possible that BTC on WAVES/BTC (as quote) has precision 8 and on BTC/LTC (as base) has precision 7? 
Anyone? Thank you in advance!
author: dar7man

comments.body:
Yes, the precision can vary amongst exchanges. 

Brg

Sorry, maybe I wasn't clear. 
I was asking if precision can very amongst markets on the same exchange?
@dar7man hi! Yes, that is very common, an exchange can have varying precision with different markets (on the same exchange). Hope that answers your question, let us know if not.
I'm not sure. I was asking if one asset (for example BTC), can have different precision on the **same exchange** but on **different markets**?
@dar7man yes, that is possible, the same asset can have different precision within different market pairs on the same exchange.

Thank you!

So, what's the point in CCTX of "precision" field in Currency structure?
How it corresponds to "precision" in Market structure?

@dar7man withdrawal precision is not always the same as trading precision. 

> How it corresponds to "precision" in Market structure?

If the exchange does not specify a per-currency precision or any currency info per se, then the highest precision from markets is taken for currencies.

If the exchange does define separate per-currency and per-market precision for BTC, then CCXT will use that where applicable.

Got it! 
Thank you very much for detailed explanation.

Ccxt output is:
```
Array
(
    [info] => Array
        (
            [status] => ok
            [data] => 472917275198035
        )

    [id] => 472917275198035
    [timestamp] =>
    [datetime] =>
    [lastTradeTimestamp] =>
    [status] =>
    [symbol] =>
    [type] =>
    [side] =>
    [price] =>
    [amount] =>
    [filled] =>

    [average] =>

```

My question is: why this method gives only id? And other values null?

But other methods like fetch_open_orders() gives correct data.
author: kleninmaxim

comments.body: If you look into the order structure, it has the `info` substructure in it, and that contains the exchange response to `createOrder`, as is, untouched. In CCXT all response structures will have that `info` member field and you can see the exchanges' responses in it, and that is documented in the CCXT Manual. When you place an order, most of the exchanges will return just the new order id. CCXT will parse that and will return whatever data is available from the exchange response. CCXT will not fill up those values, if the underlying exchange does not specify them in the response. Hope that answers your question.

title: What is expected latency for placing an order, other than network transfer latency?
body:
Microseconds?  Milliseconds?  1 second? Few seconds? Often many seconds?
Example, if 100 orders are placed, what range of times should be expected between when ccxt createOrder is called and when the order is live on the exchange order book, after subtracting the network delay/transfer time from the server to the exchange?
Another way of asking the same thing: is expected latency to place an order significantly longer than the network delay (eg if using a server in the same geography as the exchange)?  Once an order arrives at an exchange via ccxt/exchange api, is there meaningful additional delay on the exchange side before the order is live on their order book?
How much does this vary between the exchanges, and during periods of high volume?
What is a reasonable maximum delay to anticipate between the time a create order is placed in ccxt and the time that the order is live on the exchange book or executes?
Has this latency been extensively tested?
I assume that there is microsecond latency within the ccxt code itself and no network traffic required before the order goes to the exchange via the api, assuming that loadMarkets had been called previously, correct?

Thank you
author: cdcv

comments.body:
This question will never have an exact answer. There are different things involved (_if we theoretically discard network latency and consider it as zero_) :
- exchange engine: we cant answer, every exchange has different engine and it's impossible to measure their timing, it also depends on their 'high-overload' or 'low-overload' state (only they can do their internal benchmarks & measurements in their system, but I am sure they will not share this stats in public). Even if someone tested and wrote the numbers somewhere in any article, it will not be exact (because of many different factors). Order-matching and execution engine is not a fairly simple script, it has to interact with a database, consider rate-limiting and other factors.. It also depends on what strength of the servers are being used. However, to summarize in my opinion, any good exchange should be capable to place an order within several milliseconds (It's impossible to tell even an approximated number, but I don't think it would be more than 50ms even in loaded scenario, even though in very very rare cases I've experienced higher delays too).
- CCXT doesn't have its own specifics about speed - it depends on the hosted server/hardware/pc. If you execute 'createOrder' on _Pentium 1_, it might take X milliseconds, but if you run that on modern cpu, it will take Y times less. Neither this is possible to tell how many MS/MicroSecond it takes - it varies per hardware, and also per programming-language (JS, PHP, PY?), per CPU multithreading and whether CPU has enough resources at that moment (i.e. not running other extensive CPU eating apps).

and even if someone tested these, that will be very very very broad approximations (I've mentioned above my assumptions). The only way to answer that , is that you tested (google is your friend) with the specific tools from specific location with specific hardware. For the start step, you can measure (debug) the time-difference between you execute ccxt code and the moment before it send request. It might be a couple of MS i think ( lets say 1,2,3,4... depending hardware).  

@kroitor / @frosty00 let us know if you have more thoughts.
Very helpful.  Thank you.  Sounds like all of the other delays are small relative to the network latency.
Do any of the crypto exchanges offer colocalization of client servers on-site, to minimize data transmission latency?

> Do any of the crypto exchanges offer colocalization of client servers on-site, to minimize data transmission latency?

Yes, some of them do, but you will have to reach out to the exchanges themselves with this question, cause we can't really respond on their behalf in this case. Some of them offer server colocation, other will offer CPU time on their servers or within their networks.
Closing this for now, if you don't mind. Feel free to reopen it or just ask further questions if any.

title: How to enable 2FA for connection for FTX api? (Python)
body:
I would like to have the option to connect/login to my account using 2FA to enable all the measures available for safety. Unfortunately I didn't find an answer/guide that refers to this problem.

To take 2FA into account I've changed in the file /base/exchange.py:
at line 172
`twofa = ' '`

and at line 249
`'twofa': True`

So now when I try to run a basic code it's asked to me to add/include the 'twofa' variable in the `ccxt.ft({ ...})` initialization process, otherwise I won't perform any task.

But, now if I add a completely random `'twofa'=123456` it will connect to my account and perform normally. In this case to me twofa is completely secondary to `apiKey` and `secret`. It's like the important thing is to add `'twofa'` to the initialization process `ccxt.ft({ ...})` but it doesn't care if it's a correct or completely wrong 2FA

I would like to establish a connection with my account with `'apiKey'`, `'secret'` and `'twofa'` all togheter.

this is the code that I'm running with a completely random(WRONG) 2FA and it works completely fine like it's a correct 2FA code:


```
import ccxt
import pandas as pd

my_APIKEY = 'mypswd0'
my_SECRETKEY = 'mypswd1'
twofact = 123456   ##random wrong code

ftx = ccxt.ftx({
    'apiKey': my_APIKEY,
    'secret': my_SECRETKEY,
    'twofa': twofact,
    "hostname": "ftx.com",
    'options': {
        'defaultType': 'future',
                 },
})

```

How can I perform this? thank you in advance.
author: riemanncode

comments.body:
FTX API does not need a twofa setting. The 2fa code is only mentioned once in the withdraw() call.

You should use it like this:

```Python
exchange = ccxt.ftx({
    'apiKey': my_APIKEY,
    'secret': my_SECRETKEY,
})

exchange.load_markets()

params = {
    
    'code': exchange.totp ('YOUR_2FA_SECRET_HERE'),  # will yield a 6-digit timebased 2fa code
    # 'password': 'YOUR_WITHDRAWAL_PASSWORD_IF_ANY',
    
    # other overrides if necessary
}
response = exchange.withdraw (code, amount, address, tag, params)
```

Hope that answers your question. Let us know if not. Feel free to reopen this issue or just ask further questions if any.

Alternatively, you can also do it like this:

```Python
exchange = ccxt.ftx({
    'apiKey': my_APIKEY,
    'secret': my_SECRETKEY,
    'twofa': 'YOUR_2FA_SECRET_CODE_HERE'
})

exchange.load_markets()

params = {
    
    'code': exchange.oath (),  # will yield a 6-digit timebased 2fa code
    # 'password': 'YOUR_WITHDRAWAL_PASSWORD_IF_ANY',
    
    # other overrides if necessary
}
response = exchange.withdraw (code, amount, address, tag, params)
```

comments.body:
> We have received 'canceled' ccxt status in order response but in the 'info' parameters there is a 'closed' status and actual status on FTX is "Partially Filled & Cancelled". Is this behavior is OK?

Yes, that is by design. A partially-filled-then-canceled order will have status `canceled` and `amount = filled + remaining`. The `remaining` value will be > 0. All of that is logical. Let us know if that does not answer your question.

title: Move exchange specific logic into parseBalance
author: fernandocalsa

comments.body: `parseBalance` is in the base class and it populates the fields `['free', 'used', 'total']` so that `balance['free']['USDT']` and `balance['USDT']['free']` are equivalent. I don't really think it is critical to move the parsing out of `fetchBalance` at this stage.

We will eventually detach the parsing logic from fetchBalance's implementations from all exchanges, however, since `parseBalance` is already used for a different purpose, we will come up with a better name for the parser.
Closing this for now, if you don't mind. Feel free to reopen it or just ask further questions if any.

it's because you return in the exception clause

@coci as the error message says, you have to call `await exchange.close` before returning from your function, that is to release all used resources when you don't need the exchange instance anymore.

```Python
async def get(data):
	await asyncio.sleep(1)
        
        # public_api_initial() will return exchange object that connected to binance

async def main():

		symbols = []
		for j in data:
			if '/USDT' in j:
				symbols.append(j)

		feed = [{ "symbol" : i,"market_type" : ex[1],"interval" : "1m","limit" : 2,"broker_name" : ex[0]} for i in symbols]

		results = await asyncio.gather(*[get(i) for i in feed])

		await exchange.close()  # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< PUT IT HERE INSTEAD

		

start = time.time()
asyncio.run(main())
end = time.time()

print(end-start)
```

title: [okex] ether network id different than erc20 network id
author: krychla1

comments.body:
This works for me:

```Python
import ccxt
print('CCXT Version:', ccxt.__version__)
exchange = ccxt.okex({
    'apiKey': 'YOUR_API_KEY',
    'secret': 'YOUR_SECRET',
    'password': 'YOUR_API_PASSWORD',
})
markets = exchange.load_markets()
exchange.verbose = True
response = exchange.fetch_deposit_address('ETH')
print(response)
```

Let us know if you have issues with that.
ether isn't an erc20 token tho...

@frosty00 Have you actually read my first 2 sentences?

Anyway, the NETWORK attribute is not about whether it is or is not erc20 token. If you want to differentiate between mainnet currency, erc20, erc721, etc. please create another attribute, don't mess it with networks.

This network attribute should be consistent among all the exchanges for all tokens. 

I want to deposit eth to network1, I will use ```exchange.fetch_deposit_address('ETH', {network: network1})```
I want to deposit eth to network2, I will use ```exchange.fetch_deposit_address('ETH', {network: network2})```
I want to deposit avax to network1, I will use ```exchange.fetch_deposit_address('AVAX', {network: network1})```

Currently your users have to think whether it is mainnet currency, token, or whether they have to or cannot use the network parameter at all. 
```javascript
exchange.fetch_deposit_address('ETH', {network: 'ETH'})  //throws
exchange.fetch_deposit_address('ETH', {network: 'ERC20'})  //throws
exchange.fetch_deposit_address('ETH')  //passes
```
You are not going the right way, if you want to keep things simple & clear.

@krychla1 the `network` option is not meant to be the final way of unifying this aspect, it is just a mapping of one network to another for exchanges+currencies that require a network (just aliases). There's no generally unified networks in the lib yet, this is still exchange-specific. We have just started working towards the unification. Will get there as soon as possible.

`exchange.options['networks']` are used mostly for cases when, say, USDT exchange-specific network id is TRX and TRC20 for another exchange. We unify that under TRC20. And the user can use both the exchange-specific id and the unified id. But this is slightly different from a complete network generalization.

Sorry, didn't know the networks are just in their early stage, it is a good start. Please take my critics as inputs for your future design, it would be fine to have generic networks working the same across all exchanges.

title: [okex] Networks indexed improperly
body:
Dear fellows,
okex.js -> options

```                
'networks': {
    'ETH': 'ERC20',
    'TRX': 'TRC20',
    'OMNI': 'Omni',
},
```
are indexed wrongly, the networks in other parts of ccxt (exchange.currencies.networks for example) are indexed by ERC20, TRC20, etc.
I suggest to unify it (e.g. binance, kucoin, etc):
```javascript
binance: 
                'networks': {
                    'ERC20': 'ETH',
                    'TRC20': 'TRX',
                    'BEP2': 'BNB',
                    'BEP20': 'BSC',
                    'OMNI': 'OMNI',
                    'EOS': 'EOS',
                    'SPL': 'SOL',
                },
kucoin:

                'networks': {
                    'ETH': 'eth',
                    'ERC20': 'eth',
                    'TRX': 'trx',
                    'TRC20': 'trx',
                    'KCC': 'kcc',
                    'TERRA': 'luna',
                },
```

There is also issue with default value in withdraw function, which allows invalid network ID to get into withdrawal requests:
```javascript
        network = this.safeString (networks, network, network); // handle ETH>ERC20 alias
```

EDIT: the options might just need to by extended with ERC20, TRC20, etc.
author: krychla1

comments.body:
That is actually a correct mapping:

```JavaScript
'networks': {
    'ETH': 'ERC20',
    'TRX': 'TRC20',
    'OMNI': 'Omni',
},
```

‚Üë¬†That will work with all mappings ERC20, TRC20, OMNI, ETH, TRX, Omni due to how safeMethods are used with `networks`. That is done on purpose, so that all the following usages work:

```
fetchDepositAddress ('USDT', {'network':'ETH'})
fetchDepositAddress ('USDT', {'network':'ERC20'})
```


Hope that answers your question, let us know if not.

> This allows you to use ERC20 as a network only because it allows everything to be used as networks.

Yes, that is correct. We will not reject params-overrides, if the user intentionally supplies an identifier for some new blockchain that is not listed out in `networks`. The user will get an exception from the exchange if the supplied network is incorrect.

The unified identifier for ERC20 is `ERC20`, for TRC20 it is `TRC20`.
CCXT will allow the user to supply unified networks as well as exchange-specific networks by design.
I thought you would want to sanitize the inputs. I've got your point, thanks for clarification.

> I thought you would want to sanitize the inputs.

Yes, in general, we do sanitize it, but not in this specific case since the exchanges announce new listings every day, and if we hardcode that, it will be much harder to maintain. We do have some hardcode in the lib, but we would like to eventually get rid of it. Thanks for your understanding.

title: [Kucoin] ccxt.pro - way to check watched orderBooks
body:
Hi fellows!

In discord I already mentioned problems with kucoins watchOrderBooks, which time to time ends with invalid orders despite the nonce being correct. It occurs again and again (only on kucoin, I haven't found discrepancies on other exchanges so far)

To debug/handle it further I would like to create kind of a checker with fetchOrderbook by rest request to compare it with the watched orderbook. How to do that? I find it quite impossible to get same nonce from rest to match actual orderbook nonce.

Thanks.
author: krychla1

comments.body:
@krychla1 hi!

Good question! It's tricky, but I think it can be done to a certain extent:

The first approach is to keep a configurable length of history of watched nonce/timestamp-values and trigger a reconnect when the fetched nonce/timestamp-values don't intersect with history. It will require some experiments to determine the nonce/timestamp-invalidation period.

The second approach is to introduce a checksum of the orderbook and analyze the frequencies of trades, this is even harder, cause it requires watching trades along with the orderbook.

We will think about ways of adding this feature to the base code of CCXT Pro...

The second approach would be very difficult I agree. Even impossible, the trades are only a part of actions that change orderbooks. Creation and cancelation are not part of trade feeds and can't be checked by other subscription than the orderbook one.

However the first one seems feasible. 
What about to keep a cache of incoming feeds with configurable length and create a function that would be the reverse of "handleOrderBookMessage" - could apply selected depth of the cached feeds to rollback the orderbook? Of course not changing the orderbook itself, rather just returning the "rollbacked" result.
This can be used as a comparison if the fetched nonce is greater than the watched nonce.

Hi fellows!
Has this become completely dead, or do you intend to work this out?
@kroitor

late reply here, but i'll leave a note for future readers, if it'll be helpful to anyone:
- you can directly access orderbook caches with `exchange.orderbooks[symbol]`
- you can override `handleOrderBook` of any exchange, so you can create your dictionary  e.g. `myD`, where nonces will be keys, so on each trigger of `handleOrderBook` you store the orderbook object in `myD` and then use `fetchOrderBook`, which would give you fetched orderbook (with nonce)  you might be able to locate the saved orderbook in `myD` by that nonce

if there are still any issues, let us know

author: israel-gonzalezmedina

comments.body:
At this moment, it seems to me the way (to create two separate objects), and as they inherit from binance, there is no need to create `new ccxt.binance` separately, as they will do everything whatever `binance` class can do. as you might seen in implementation, the `options` parts are only different in `binanceusdm/binancecoinm`:

binanceusdm:
```
            'options': {
                'defaultType': 'future',
                'marginTypes': {},
                ...
            },
```

binancecoinm:

```
                'defaultType': 'delivery',
                ...
            },
```

unfortunately, I can't see any simple way to initiate only one binance-object and manage switching from one to another type, because of the dependancy-chain (i.e. separate fetch-markets, permitted currencies, etc...), so viable way is to have 2 exchange objects.

however, if you want to trade on spot too, then you will need 3rd initiated object (`new binance()`) as the above two only works with their fields and not on spot.

title: ByBit Close Position
body:
- OS: MacOs
- Programming Language version: Python 3.9.4
- CCXT version: 1.60.9

```
symbol = 'SOLUSDT'
trade_res = exchange.create_order(symbol, amount=1, type='Market', side='Buy')
```

The above snippet buys 1 SOL against USDT. When I try to close the position by placing a sell order, I see that ByBit placed another Short position on SOL without closing the Long one (2 positions appear in the console)

How do I close a current open position on ByBit using ccxt?
author: mhd-adam

comments.body:
You need to set the `reduce_only` param to `True` to place a closing order on Bybit. To my knowledge there is unfortunately no way to set this as the default behavior on Bybit, and you will need to track your position on your end or use a try/except to catch and re-place an order as opening if a closing order attempt fails, but of course this will count as 2 API requests.

```
symbol = 'SOLUSDT'
trade_res = exchange.create_order(symbol, amount=1, type='Market', side='Buy', params={"reduce_only": True})
```
It worked for me! Thank you!

title: Question: best practice to fetch all transactions/ledgers
body: I just have a general question of whether there are any best practices for fetching all transactions/ledger items for a given account. Exchanges like Binance have a lot of currencies so going through all of those for an account seems overkill and slow. I was thinking about fetching the account's balances and then just fetching transactions/ledger entries for those returned currency codes, but that doesn't work if the user used to have a currency but does not anymore (except if there's dust left). Is there any other way to do this without having to go through all currency codes an exchange has?
author: steebchen

comments.body:
Well, I think there is no common way to get all transactions of all currencies universally over all exchanges. Part of exchanges might have a 'bulk' way but other exchanges may not. 
I advise to do a bit more research into the specific exchange API DOCS you are interested in, and find out there, if they support bulk/batch endpoint for getting all transactions, then it means it will be callable from CCXT (mostly with implicit API).

Another way you was mentioning, might be to iterate through your last X (i.e. 100) withdrawal/deposits and also trades, and from there, list-out all currencies, create an array, and iterate only through those array. This will much narrow-down your diapason (instead of iterating through all 700s currencies).  Or maybe you have a thought yourself, in what ways you have interacted with those currencies (other than deposit/withdrawal or trading) and try to get the list of 'those' coins that way, and after you have the desired list of coins, iterate through those currencies to fetch transactions for them.  

let us know if any issue there.

title: Python ratelimiter broken
body:
The python rateLimiter is broken in the newest version.
I tested this on python 3.7 and 3.8 (Debian and CentOS)

The following snippet should return, but it is stuck after the first loop.

```
import asyncio
import ccxt.async_support


async def main():
    exchange1 = ccxt.async_support.hitbtc({"enableRateLimit": True})
    exchange2 = ccxt.async_support.hitbtc({"enableRateLimit": True})
    for i in range(0, 20):
        await exchange1.throttle(exchange1.rateLimit)
        await exchange2.throttle(exchange2.rateLimit)
        print("Round done")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```
author: brandsimon

comments.body:
The snippet works for binance, so I changed the rateLimit to 50 (binance has 50, hitbtc 1500).
This works, but instead of waiting 50ms, it waits 5 seconds.

@brandsimon the usage is wrong it should be:

```
import asyncio
import ccxt.async_support


async def main():
    exchange1 = ccxt.async_support.hitbtc({"enableRateLimit": True})
    exchange2 = ccxt.async_support.hitbtc({"enableRateLimit": True})
    for i in range(0, 20):
        await exchange1.throttle(1)
        await exchange2.throttle(1)
        print("Round done")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```
the argument exchange.rateLimit is deprecated now we have dynamic costs for calls in binance.js
@brandsimon the new version of `throttle()` accepts the call `cost` instead of `rateLimit`.

```Python
import asyncio
import ccxt.async_support

async def main():
    exchange1 = ccxt.async_support.hitbtc({"enableRateLimit": True})
    exchange2 = ccxt.async_support.hitbtc({"enableRateLimit": True})
    for i in range(0, 20):
        await asyncio.gather(*[
            exchange1.throttle(1),
            exchange2.throttle(1),
        ])
        print("Round done")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    asyncio.run(main())
```
This snippet prints a line every 1.5 sec, according to hitbtc's rate limit setting.
@brandsimon yes, moreover, enableRateLimit is true by default now.
Great, thank you :)

title: Buy USD with CCXT
body:
Hello, 

I just wanted to know if there's anyway with CCXT where I can buy USD using debit card/ACH payment depositing and put the amount in wallet for trade in future, say in Binance?

Please label this as question
author: soumyadeeproy12

comments.body: Hi! No, CCXT does not have any specific functionality to cover your deposits, since that is beyond the scope of the lib. CCXT lets you do everything the exchange allows you to do, call any endpoint with any set of params, as you like, but CCXT cannot talk to the banks and other structures required in the depositing process. CCXT is about cryptocurrency exchanges, mostly. Hope that answers your question. The lib will allow you to move funds between your accounts within the exchange, and it will even allow you to withdraw from one exchange to another, but you should first deposit to the initial exchange on your own.

title: What is the recommended pattern to watch a large amount of orderbooks?
author: fvsgit

comments.body:
Hi,

> I have some questions regarding the reccommended pattern / implementation in nodejs to watch a large amount of order books on Binance. Before I get to the questions, let me explain what I want to do: I would like to watch for example 100 or more order books. The purpose is for a triangular arbitrage bot, so I want to watch as many markets as possible to find the best opportunities.

In general, doing all of the above from a single machine is a bad idea. Usually, you have to architect your app in a scalable way. You can get away with a few dozens orderbooks on average, but not more. A single connection becomes a bottleneck. 

Instead of watching hundreds of orderbooks from the same application, corps usually invest time and money into building an architecture, where there's a swarm of order book listeners, each listening for a few orderbooks, controlled by central business logic that sends orders here and there.

Personally, I would suggest making a working proof of concept or a minimal viable product that would function with 3-5-10 pairs from a single machine, and then scale that up to multiple machines and hundreds of symbols.

> If i run the same code but for 66 orderbooks, it freezes and it seems like the orderbooks are only updated once. After several minutes the orderbooks are still not updated.

The orderbooks are only updated when something happens on the market in question (an order is changed or added or closed).

Let us know if that does not answer your question.

Hi Igor,

Thanks for getting back to me. I was thinking already of developing these orderbook listeners, but first wanted to ensure I am not over engineering something here. Your idea of building it for example with a small amount of markets sounds good.

Thank you for the great API and the active work on it.

Can you share just a little bit more detail on how using multiple listeners to retrieve many order books in real time would need to work?  What the requirements for each listener to avoid being closed down by the exchange(s)?  I presume each listener needs a different IP address, needs to only listen to a limited number of symbols as you say, and needs to use the public exchange api.  Anything else?  Given that the listener code could be very, very simple, what are some simple ways to achieve this as a swarm this without over-engineering the swarm architecture?  Can you recommend the simplest tools you've seen people using to do this, or what you'd suggest?  Thank you.

title: What is the best practice to write custom rate limiter for multiple CCXT exchange instances?
body:
Hello. I need to run large amount of exchange instances with different api keys(to call REST API with fetchMyTrades and another methods). What is the best way to handle rate limits of exchange between all of them? I can not found any examples about technique in docs. I see good examples about reusing exchange instance, but if I uderstand correctly this not suitable for my situation. Should I control rateLimit field somehow for each instance? Maybe you have some example of custom rate limiter?
Thanks!

- OS: Any
- Programming Language version: Node.js 14.x
- CCXT version: Any
author: koftyan

comments.body:
I had to solve the same problem some time ago.

While you are sending all requests from one IP address (regardless the different API keys), the exchange can block your IP address for the reason of rate-limit or DDOS errors.

So you have two ways to avoid this:
1. Limit the rate of the requests of all exchange instances.
2. Use different IP addresses for every instance of the exchange. But this does not save you from problems of blocking IP if instance will send requests too fast.

I used the following approach:

* For every exchange instance dedicated proxy-server was bought. I used the separate VPS's for every instance before, but maintaining such an infrastructure is much more difficult than using proxy servers. 

To use the proxy you need to update the exchange instance with the dict:
 `exchange_instance.proxies = {'https': 'YOUR_PROXY_SERVER'}`

* To work with DDOS and RATE-limit errors of the every instance I use the following code:

**note**: the code is simplified. For every exchange I write custom `exception_handler()` with much more handlers.

```
    def exception_handler(self, func: classmethod, *args, **kwargs):

        while True:
            try:
                data = func(*args, **kwargs)

            except (ccxt.DDoSProtection, ccxt.RateLimitExceeded):
                self.increase_rate_limit()  # decrease speed of the requests to avoid blocking the proxy in the future
                self.change_proxy_server()  # because you current proxy is blocked now for some time
                continue

            ...................
            ...................

            return data

    def increase_rate_limit(self):
        self.rateLimit += 500

```

Thanks for your reply!
I am currently using similar approach with proxies but it is very expensive in my case(now I am running about 3000 instances, but in future this count may be increased up to 10000). 
Now I want to sacrifice a little the speed of updates, but try to get rid of the use of proxy servers as much as possible.

I can only guess your trading strategy, but if your one exchange instance works with the only one market (one pair), the number of instances can be significantly decreased  by increasing number of pairs one instance is working with. But this is not a question of the CCXT library, but of a programming approach. 

It might be time to try asynchronous code and websockets also. Not all exchanges support websockets, but the largest exchanges do.

@koftyan where do you get quality proxies ? I tried with residential proxies but after like 5 requests i get always `The selected relay is offline or busy processing other threads` and also the speed is unacceptable for me.
This is related: #9470 so maybe that also answers also this topic as some degree.
issue has been stale, so closing for now. however, any future readers are welcome to add their notes in this thread.

title: Bitfinex - fetch_my_trades()
body:
- OS: Ubuntu 20.4
- Programming Language version: python 3.7
- CCXT version: 1.52.94

```python
symbol = 'BTC/USD'
day = 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000
start_time = exchange.parse8601 ('2021-02-25T22:27:44.000')
now = exchange.milliseconds ()
all_trades = []

while start_time < now:

    print('------------------------------------------------------------------')
    print('Fetching trades from', exchange.iso8601(start_time))
    end_time = start_time + day

    trades = exchange.fetch_my_trades(
        symbol=symbol, 
        since=start_time, 
        limit=None, 
        params={
            'endTime': end_time
        }
    )
    if len(trades):
        last_trade = trades[-1]
        start_time = last_trade['timestamp'] + 1
        all_trades += trades
    else:
        start_time = end_time

print('Fetched', len(all_trades), 'trades')
for i in range(0, len(all_trades)):
    trade = all_trades[i]
    print (i, trade['id'], trade['datetime'], trade['amount'])
```

When using `fetch_my_trades()` on either `bitfinex` and `bitfinex2`, the `since` date has no effect and responses return only the last 50 trades for `bitfinex` and 25 for `bitfinex2` api's.

Any help appreciated

Thanks
author: JamesKBowler

comments.body:
@JamesKBowler  I believe that's because you're not passing a limit to the fetch_my_trade method. In those cases, the default limit will be used, so if the number of trades within the range you've defined with the since parameter is bigger than the limit itself the response will be capped at the limit value. Just bear in mind that these limits may not be high as well. During my tests, I was able to retrieve 999 trades in a single request from the public API, but that limit can vary depending on the endpoint.
(cc @kroitor )
Above answer by @carlosmiei was correct. I'll mark the issue as closed. Let us know if you experience any issue with CCXT.

title: Documentation not clear on Canceling Orders
body:
In the documentation of Canceling Orders it is not clear what is returned by exchange.cancelOrder.
It seems that sometimes it's only a string with the id and sometimes the complete Order structure object. Are there other cases? Is this exchange dependant? Is it only missing some implementations in some exchanges?
author: tuloski

comments.body:
Hello @tuloski,
Unfortunately, there is no standard response from the exchanges when canceling an order. Every exchange has its own way of doing it (some return the created order, some return only a success status, etc) so yes, it is exchange dependant. When the exchange returns with the created order, we return it parsed, otherwise, we just forward the exchange response.

Just to add to this issue and to clarify:

We have 3 unified methods for canceling orders:

1. `cancelOrder` for canceling a single order by id, must return an order structure. If it's not unified in some exchanges or does not return a unified order structure ‚Äì¬†that has to be fixed in the lib and that is a work that still has to be done, @tuloski @carlosmiei let me know if you can find or fix any occurrences of those.
2. `cancelOrders` for canceling multiple orders by multiple ids. It currently returns exchange-specific responses everywhere, since it's quite hard to unify. It should probably return a dict of canceled and non-canceled ids.
3. `cancelAllOrders` for canceling multiple orders with or without a symbol. It currently also returns exchange-specific response everywhere for the same reason.

(1) Should already be mostly unified.
(2) + (3) is still a question on how to better unify those, we are gathering exchange response samples for an overview later.

title: Is connection dropped on 'ping-pong keepalive missing on time' error?
body:
Periodically for FTX, Binance/Futures error `Connection to [stream_name] timed out due to a ping-pong keepalive missing on time` occurred when `watchTicker` method is running. Is connection closed after that error and I need to resubscribe for all symbols?

- OS: DEBIAN (Docker)
- Programming Language version: NodeJS
- CCXT version: Pro version: 0.6.81
author: wunderb1t

comments.body: The same connection is shared across all subscriptions, and most often if one of them times out, all of that become unresponsive, and the entire connection with all its subscriptions must be re-established. We also have plans on adding a better connection manager that will restore your subscriptions automatically and will allow subscribing to many symbols at once. Let us know if the above does not answer your question. If that happens too frequently, please, let us know, we will investigate further.

title: Transfer between Binance wallets return status, datetime and timestamp = None
body:
Hello all,

I noticed that transfer between Binance wallets return some missing information, please find an example:

```
b.transfer('USDT', 1, 'future', 'spot')

{'info': {'tranId': '65052934028'},
 'id': '65052934028',
 'timestamp': None,
 'datetime': None,
 'currency': 'USDT',
 'amount': 1,
 'fromAccount': 'future',
 'toAccount': 'spot',
 'status': None}
```

As you can see status, timestamp and datetime are set to None even when transfer is successful. It's a minor issue but it's useful to have these data in order to monitor transfers.

Best,
Kinzowa
author: Kinzowa

comments.body: Hi! The `info` structure contains the response from the exchange "as is", untouched: `'info': {'tranId': '65052934028'},` ‚Üê there's no timestamp there, therefore it's not populated. This is documented throughout the Manual ‚Äì¬†not all exchanges will provide all the fields in all the structures. If you need a timestamp, you can just call `exchange.milliseconds()` or `exchange.iso8601(exchange.milliseconds())`. Hope that answers your question. Let us know if not.
Thanks Igor, I will do that

```Python
import ccxtpro
import ccxt
from asyncio import get_event_loop, gather

async def watch_orders(exchange, symbol):
```

title: What Time Does The Day Roll Over?
body:
Quick question: When do daily 'candles' roll over in ccxt? I am pulling daily data on a US server and for my system I need to know when the date stamps roll over into the new day/date. My understanding thus far is that it happens at 0:00 GMT. 

If correct then the roll over would be e.g. at 8:00pm in NYC, and 1:00am in London.

Can you please confirm or correct?
author: mmehrle

comments.body: Hi! Yes, all unified timestamps should be in UTC. Exchange-specific `info`s may have timestamps in other timezones, but CCXT converts them to UTC in the outer unified layer. If you find any inconsistencies, please let us know.
WOW - that was fast. You are the man. BTW, ccxt kicks ass - love it.

Follow up question. I'm setting up a cron job and my sys admin asked me if we are talking about UTC or GMT here. Because GMT accounts for DST while UTC does not. My 'guess' would be that exchanges use UTC but I just wanted to make sure.

Thanks in advance.
Never mind - you already answered that it's in UTC. My apologies - I have not gotten much sleep in the past few weeks :-}

title: Arbitrage Trading question
body:
What would be the proper method to performing arbitrage trades with ccxt?

Like for example do you need to have money already deposited in each exchange? this is the main question im wondering if theres some sort of most efficient way of approaching this.

thanks
author: adamrg73

comments.body:
I don't think it's a question related to ccxt.
It's more about trading strategies for arbitrage.
BTW the steps are something like:

- Subscribe to books with watchOrderbook() to get the most recent books via ws (ccxt.pro)
- Implement the arbitrage strategy and calculate the trade prices and volumes
- Send trading orders with ccxt createLimitSellOrder (or buy order, or market orders depending on the strategies)

> * via ws

what is ws?

> > * via ws
> 
> what is ws?

websocket

> > > * via ws
> > 
> > 
> > what is ws?
> 
> websocket

It's only available on ccxt.pro, right?
@HokhyTann yes, it's available in ccxt.pro only at this time.

do you have to have funds in all the exchanges already in there before the orders are placed? I just wana make sure im not missing a technique? or do you send the funds in quick with the ccxt api and then do the trade? these details someone please outline the best steps most people use.

> do you have to have funds in all the exchanges already in there before the orders are placed? I just wana make sure im not missing a technique? or do you send the funds in quick with the ccxt api and then do the trade? these details someone please outline the best steps most people use.

Please, this is not a forum on trading strategies. The best arbitrageurs won't discuss with you their technique learned in years of experience and trial/errors.
Consider taking a course on finance/trading. Arbitrage trading HAS risks and it requires some knowledge.
Please consider also closing this issue.

@adamrg73 

> do you have to have funds in all the exchanges already in there before the orders are placed?

Yes, that's the only way to keep up with the arbitrage speeds on most pairs.

> or do you send the funds in quick with the ccxt api and then do the trade?

That would be too slow, most of inter-exchange opportunities exists for seconds (if not milliseconds), and if your transfer takes minutes to confirm, you may lose the opportunity. There may still be some opportunities that exist long enough to catch them, but you should expect a lot of competition anyways.

In general, I think, @tuloski is right, we cannot really discuss it in-depth in this format, cause general arbitrage is a very wide field of ideas, covering it would require writing a book here on just this single issue alone. It's a question too vague. We can discuss concrete questions or technical questions on CCXT though. I would close this issue for now, feel free to reopen it if you run into difficulties.

title: Stale Price Feed from Binance USDT Futures & FTX
body:
Hi Kroitor,

I think I'm getting a stale/delayed price feed from Binance USDT Futures and FTX. I only need the Best Bid & Offer from each of the exchanges pushed in real-time (I don't need orderbooks). Sometimes the FTX price or the Binance price just stops updating. Is there anything in the code you can see that would be causing this?

import threading
import asyncio
import ccxtpro
import loggin_util
from definitions.exchanges import Exchanges
from definitions.trading_util import ConnectionState
import ccxtpro_exchanges
import definitions.app_values as apv


# from principal import Principal


class DataFeedManager(threading.Thread):
    def __init__(self, exchange: Exchanges, symbol_name: str, data_coin_command, print_info: bool,
                 entry_delta: float, exit_delta: float, entry_size: float, _data_feed_stopped,
                 _executing_methods_event, assigned_pair_id):
        threading.Thread.__init__(self)
        self.exchange = exchange
        self.symbol_name = symbol_name
        self.print_info = print_info
        self.print_info = False  # for testing
        self.bid = 0.0
        self.ask = 0.0
        self.entry_delta = entry_delta
        self.exit_delta = exit_delta
        self.entry_size = entry_size
        self.logger = loggin_util.create_logger(__name__ + '_' + self.exchange.name + '_' +
                                                self.symbol_name.replace('/', ''))
        self.conn_state = ConnectionState.DISCONNECTED
        self.data_coin_command = data_coin_command
        self.data_feed_enabled = True
        self.data_feed_stopped = _data_feed_stopped
        self.executing_methods_event = _executing_methods_event
        self.binance_pro = ccxtpro.binance({'enableRateLimit': True,
                                            'options': {
                                                'defaultType': 'future',
                                            }})
        self.ftx_pro = ccxtpro.ftx({'enableRateLimit': True})
        self.assigned_pair_id = assigned_pair_id

        # print(self.symbol_id.replace('/', ''))

    async def get_tick(self):
        exchange_switcher = {
            Exchanges.binance: ccxtpro.binance({'enableRateLimit': True,
                                                'apiKey': apv.binance_api_key,
                                                'secret': apv.binance_secret_key,
                                                'options': {
                                                    'defaultType': 'future',
                                                    'watchTicker': {
                                                        'name': 'bookTicker'
                                                    }
                                                }}),
            Exchanges.ftx: ccxtpro.ftx({'enableRateLimit': True}),
        }
        exchange = exchange_switcher.get(self.exchange)
        while self.data_feed_stopped.wait():

            if not self.data_feed_enabled:
                print("Stopping Data Feed")
                self.data_feed_stopped.clear()
                print("Data Feed Stopped? %s" % self.data_feed_stopped)
                break

            if self.print_info: print("----------------------")
            if self.print_info: print("data_feed_enabled: %s" % self.data_feed_enabled)
            if self.print_info: print(exchange.id)
            if self.print_info: print("Symbol: ", self.symbol_name)

            try:
                # order_book = await exchange.watch_order_book(self.symbol_name)
                order_book = await exchange.watch_ticker(self.symbol_name)
            except Exception as e:
                self.conn_state = ConnectionState.DISCONNECTED
                self.logger.error('Disconnected')
                print("Exception: ", e)
                continue
            if self.conn_state == ConnectionState.DISCONNECTED:
                self.logger.info('Connected')
                self.conn_state = ConnectionState.CONNECTED

            # self.bid = order_book['bids'][0][0] if len(order_book['bids']) > 0 else None
            # self.ask = order_book['asks'][0][0] if len(order_book['asks']) > 0 else None
            self.bid = order_book['bid'] if order_book['bid'] is not None else self.bid
            self.ask = order_book['ask'] if order_book['ask'] is not None else self.ask
            spread = (self.ask - self.bid) if (self.bid and self.ask) else None
            mid = (self.bid + self.ask) / 2 if (self.bid and self.ask) else None
            if self.print_info: print("bid: ", self.bid)
            if self.print_info: print("ask: ", self.ask)
            if self.print_info: print("spread: ", spread)
            if self.print_info: print("mid: ", mid)
            self.data_coin_command(self.symbol_name,
                                   self.bid,
                                   self.ask,
                                   self.entry_delta,
                                   self.exit_delta,
                                   self.entry_size,
                                   self.executing_methods_event,
                                   self.assigned_pair_id)

    def run(self):
        asyncio.run(self.get_tick())

title: OHLCV historic data loop
body:
Hello guys, im really a novice with ccxt and pyhton, sorry if this is trivial.
after fetching data  the returned csv data loops from end date back to start date in the file. Thanks in advance for help 

- OS: Ubuntu
- Programming Language version:3.8
- CCXT version: 1.48.25

```
import ccxt
import calendar
from datetime import datetime, date, timedelta
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

ftx = ccxt.ftx()

def min_ohlcv(dt, pair, limit):
    # UTC native object
    since = calendar.timegm(dt.utctimetuple())*1000
    ohlcv1 = ftx.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe='1d', since=since, limit=limit)
    ohlcv2 = ftx.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe='1d', since=since, limit=limit)
    ohlcv = ohlcv1 + ohlcv2
    return ohlcv

def ohlcv(dt, pair, period='1d'):
    ohlcv = []
    limit = 1000
    if period == '1m':
        limit = 720
    elif period == '1d':
        limit = 365
    elif period == '1h':
        limit = 24
    elif period == '5m':
        limit = 288
    for i in dt:
        start_dt = datetime.strptime(i, "%Y%m%d")
        since = calendar.timegm(start_dt.utctimetuple())*1000
        if period == '1d':
            ohlcv.extend(min_ohlcv(start_dt, pair, limit))
        else:
            ohlcv.extend(ftx.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe=period, since=since, limit=limit))
    df = pd.DataFrame(ohlcv, columns = ['Time', 'Open', 'High', 'Low', 'Close', 'Volume'])
    df['Time'] = [datetime.fromtimestamp(float(time)/1000) for time in df['Time']]
    df['Open'] = df['Open'].astype(np.float64)
    df['High'] = df['High'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Low'] = df['Low'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Close'] = df['Close'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Volume'] = df['Volume'].astype(np.float64)
    df.set_index('Time', inplace=True)
    return df


start_day = "20200119"
start_dt = datetime.strptime(start_day, "%Y%m%d")
end_day = "20210419"
end_dt = datetime.strptime(end_day, "%Y%m%d")
days_num = (end_dt - start_dt).days + 1
datelist = [start_dt + timedelta(days=x) for x in range(days_num)]
datelist = [date.strftime("%Y%m%d") for date in datelist]

df = ohlcv(datelist, 'BTC-PERP', '1d')


df.to_csv('data/btc_price.csv')
```

title: How long to create an order
body:
Hello,

I find your library very useful.

But with PHP between the moment I open a PHP page that will create an order and where it appear on Binance it takes 3 seconds.
It may seem fast but on Binance Future with a leverage level these 3 seconds can make you lose money.

Do these 3 seconds come more from my linux machine?
From PHP ? Unoptimized language 
Or Binance? Server time response.

Thank you
author: zed2zed

comments.body: This can depend on a variety of factors. Depending on your internet connection and your location relative to Binance servers, the round-trip latency may be very high. Note that depending on your location, the Binance matching engine may have significantly higher latency than the Binance website. In general you can assume that processor time on your end << network latency.

title: Is it safe to use prices from the orderdepths directly in regard of price precision
body:
OS: Windows Server 2019 Datacenter
Programming Language version: Node.js 15.3.0
CCXT version: 1.38.89
Exchange: All Exchanges
Method: precision and limits

Hello!

I have a question about the precision when it comes to prices for a symbol when creating limit and marketorders.

For example we can get the orderbook like below:
```
(async () => {
const exchange = new ccxt.bitfinex({ enableRateLimit: true, agent, 'timeout': 10000 });
const orderbook = await exchange.fetchOrderBook("ETH/BTC", 5);
console.log(orderbook);
})()
```
This gives a structure like this with price and volume per orderdepth:
```
    [ 0.030365, 7.76077035 ],
    [ 0.030366, 7 ],
    [ 0.030368, 0.069 ],
    [ 0.03037, 1.19718266 ],
    [ 0.030376, 12 ]
```

My question is how safe it would be to directly just use the price from any of the orderdepths when `createOrder(...)`
What I mean, would it be safe to just take a price without using the `exchange.decimalToPrecision` to round it to correct precision.

Would it be safe to just take the prices from the orderdepths from all exchanges or should one anyway use `exchange.decimalToPrecision` function for safety?

Thank you!
author: jackpotcityco

comments.body: @jackpotcityco Hi! It should be safe to use those prices directly, CCXT will format those values according to exchange precision before sending them out. Let us know if you run into any issues with that.

Hi! Thank you, that is great. Then I will only focus on the precision for the amounts then.

Thank you for the help!

title: Maximum Data Per Symbol Prior To Fetch_OHLCV?
body:
I'm attempting to pull the maximum amount of data for a number of symbols from bittrex which seems to offer the most historical data of the available exchanges. I'm encountering a strange problem with altcoins like '4ART/BTC' for example. When I pull 3 weeks worth of daily data it works fine. However if I attempt to set the start date to something like 1/1/2017 I get a completely empty dataframe instead of the maximum amount of data.

How can I avoid that? I simply need to pull the maximum amount of data for each symbol in the exchange. Test code below. If I use 10 or 20 weeks as the param it works. But 52 weeks or more returns an empty df.

So is it possible to query the maximum amount of available data prior to doing a fetch_ohlcv?

```
from datetime import datetime, date
from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta
import os
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import ccxt
from datetime import datetime as dt
import calendar

debug = True
exchange = ccxt.bittrex({'enableRateLimit': True})
data_path = '/Users/xxxxx/my_path/'

def min_ohlcv(start, pair, limit):
    # UTC native object
    since = calendar.timegm(start.utctimetuple()) * 1000
    ohlcv1 = exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe='1m', since=since, limit=limit)
    ohlcv2 = exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe='1m', since=since, limit=limit)
    ohlcv = ohlcv1 + ohlcv2
    return ohlcv

def ohlcv(start, pair, period='1d'):
    ohlcv = []
    limit = 1000
    if period == '1m':
        limit = 720
    elif period == '1d':
        limit = 365
    elif period == '1h':
        limit = 24
    elif period == '5m':
        limit = 288
    for i in start:
        start_dt = datetime.strptime(i, "%Y%m%d")
        since = calendar.timegm(start_dt.utctimetuple()) * 1000
        if period == '1m':
            ohlcv.extend(min_ohlcv(start_dt, pair, limit))
        else:
            ohlcv.extend(exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe=period, since=since, limit=limit))
    if period == '1d':
        df = pd.DataFrame(ohlcv, columns=['Date', 'Open', 'High', 'Low', 'Close', 'Volume'])
        df['Date'] = [datetime.fromtimestamp(float(time) / 1000).strftime('%m/%d/%Y') for time in df['Date']]
    else:
        df = pd.DataFrame(ohlcv, columns=['Time', 'Open', 'High', 'Low', 'Close', 'Volume'])
        df['Time'] = [datetime.fromtimestamp(float(time) / 1000) for time in df['Time']]

    df['Open'] = df['Open'].astype(np.float64)
    df['High'] = df['High'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Low'] = df['Low'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Close'] = df['Close'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Volume'] = df['Volume'].astype(np.float64)
    if period == '1d':
        df.set_index('Date', inplace=True)
    else:
        df.set_index('Time', inplace=True)
    return df


def fetch_data(coin, weeks = 52):
    step_back_days = dt.today().weekday()  # it's supposed to start Mondays
    step_back_days += (weeks * 7)
    start_date = dt.today() - relativedelta(days=step_back_days)
    current_week = "{}-{}".format(start_date.strftime("%Y"), start_date.isocalendar()[1])
    print("Starting at week # {}...".format(current_week))

    midnight = dt.combine(start_date, dt.min.time())
    from_date = (midnight - relativedelta(days=step_back_days)).strftime('%Y%m%d')
    # print('From date: {}'.format(from_date))
    from_dt = [from_date]

    ohlcv_file_name = "%s_%s.%s" % (coin.replace('/', '_'), datetime.today().isocalendar()[1], 'csv')
    fullpath = '{}{}'.format(data_path, ohlcv_file_name)

    if os.path.exists(fullpath):
        os.remove(fullpath)

    if debug:
        print('\nFetching daily data for {} starting on {}...'.format(coin, start_date.strftime('%Y-%m-%d')))
    df_symbol = ohlcv(from_dt, coin, '1d')
    if debug:
        print('Retrieved {} days:'.format(len(df_symbol)))
    if not len(df_symbol):
        if debug:
            print('{} only has no data - skipping...'.format(coin))
        if os.path.exists(fullpath):
            os.remove(fullpath)
    if debug:
        print(df_symbol.tail(7))

    df_symbol.to_csv(fullpath, index=True)

fetch_data('4ART/BTC', 52)
```
author: mmehrle

comments.body:
Okay, I just figured out that when I remove the start date and the limit it pulls the maximum data:

Instead of:
`ohlcv.extend(exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe=period, since=since, limit=limit))`

I used this:
`ohlcv.extend(exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe=period))`

By the way, what does ohlcv.extend do?

it's a bit old topic, but as OP stated he solved the issue and posted solution himself, the issue is considered as closed.
feel free to re-open the issue if you face any problems

title: What is the difference between currency_to_precision() and amount_to_precision() ?
body:
Hello,

I try to figure out what is the difference between the two because amount is usually an amount of currency on spot markets. So `amount_to_precision()` can be used to properly format the precision of an order but could you tell me when one should use `currency_to_precision()` ?

Thank you,
author: Kinzowa

comments.body:
Hi!

The difference is the first argument, one is for market trading precision, the other is for currency funding precision.

```Python
exchange.amount_to_precision(symbol, amount)  # ccxt uses this for orders
                           # ‚Üì vs ‚Üë
exchange.currency_to_precision(code, amount)  # ccxt uses this for withdrawals, transfers, loans
```

```Python
exchange.amount_to_precision('BTC/USDT', 123.4567890)  # format amount to base precision for orders
exchange.currency_to_precision('BTC', 123.4567890)  # format to precision for withdrawals, transfers, loans
```

Let us know if that does not answer your question.

title: Difficulties pulling reliable daily closing data
body:
I was having issues with pulling daily closing data. Every time I ran it I got different results. Eventually I thought of setting the from_date to midnight the previous day and now it seems to be consistent. See the test below:

```
from datetime import datetime, date, timedelta
from dateutil.relativedelta import relativedelta
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import calendar
import ccxt

symbols = ['AAVE/BTC']
exchange = ccxt.binance()

def min_ohlcv(dt, pair, limit):
    # UTC native object
    since = calendar.timegm(dt.utctimetuple())*1000
    ohlcv1 = exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe='1m', since=since, limit=limit)
    ohlcv2 = exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe='1m', since=since, limit=limit)
    ohlcv = ohlcv1 + ohlcv2
    return ohlcv

def ohlcv(dt, pair, period='1d'):
    ohlcv = []
    limit = 1000
    if period == '1m':
        limit = 720
    elif period == '1d':
        limit = 365
    elif period == '1h':
        limit = 24
    elif period == '5m':
        limit = 288
    for i in dt:
        start_dt = datetime.strptime(i, "%Y%m%d")
        since = calendar.timegm(start_dt.utctimetuple())*1000
        if period == '1m':
            ohlcv.extend(min_ohlcv(start_dt, pair, limit))
        else:
            ohlcv.extend(exchange.fetch_ohlcv(symbol=pair, timeframe=period, since=since, limit=limit))
    if period == '1d':
        df = pd.DataFrame(ohlcv, columns = ['Date', 'Open', 'High', 'Low', 'Close', 'Volume'])
        df['Date'] = [datetime.fromtimestamp(float(time)/1000).strftime('%m/%d/%Y') for time in df['Date']]
    else:
        df = pd.DataFrame(ohlcv, columns = ['Time', 'Open', 'High', 'Low', 'Close', 'Volume'])
        df['Time'] = [datetime.fromtimestamp(float(time)/1000) for time in df['Time']]
    
    df['Open'] = df['Open'].astype(np.float64)
    df['High'] = df['High'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Low'] = df['Low'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Close'] = df['Close'].astype(np.float64)
    df['Volume'] = df['Volume'].astype(np.float64)
    if period == '1d':
        df.set_index('Date', inplace=True)
    else:
        df.set_index('Time', inplace=True)
    return df

days = 120
today = datetime.today()
midnight = datetime.combine(today, datetime.min.time())
from_date = (midnight - relativedelta(days=days)).strftime('%Y%m%d')

print('From date: {}'.format(from_date))
dt = [from_date]

prices = pd.DataFrame()
for symbol in symbols:
    df_symbol = ohlcv(dt, symbol, '1d')
    prices[symbol] = df_symbol['Close']

#clip last row
prices = prices[:-1]
    
print(prices.tail())
print('Length: {} days.'.format(len(prices)))
```

This looks correct to me and the output is now consistent. But I'd really appreciate it if someone with experience in pulling daily crypto closing data would confirm it. Thanks in advance.

body:
- OS: running in docker file using image `python:3`
- Programming Language version: running in docker file using image `python:3`

```
 def place_order(self, order, ticker):
        try:
            # load order info
            symbol = order.symbol
            bid, ask = ticker['bid'], ticker['ask']
            buy = order.buy  # boolean representing buy/sell

            exchange = load_exchange(order.exchange)
            if buy:
                if order.exchange == 'binance':
                    price = float(order.buy_max)
                elif order.exchange == 'bittrex':
                    price = exchange.amount_to_precision(ask * 1.05)
                order.amount = self.config.btc / price
            else:  # sell
                price = bid
                revenue = order.amount * price
                revenue -= order.amount * order.bought_at
                logging.info("bought at: {0} - sold at {1}".format(order.bought_at, price))
                logging.info("total revenue of order: {0}".format(revenue))

            logging.info('amount: {0}'.format(order.amount))
            amount = exchange.amount_to_lots(symbol, order.amount)
            logging.info('amount(lots): {0}'.format(amount))
            self.create_order_on_market(buy, order.exchange, symbol, price, amount)
        except Exception as e:
            logging.error(e)
            self.pushover.send_pushover(
                "{0} order failed for {1} on {2} with error {3}".format(
                    'Buy' if buy else 'Sell', order.coin, order.exchange, e
                )
            )
```

title: When does actually the watch_ticker function refresh?
body:
Dear contributor,

I have gone through the ccxt documentation and the answer to the following question is not clear to me. When the following code line (python) is executed:
order_book = await exchange.watch_order_book(symbol)
every time the order book for that symbol is updated the function will return the whole new order book. However, if we type the following code line:
ticker = await exchange.watch_ticker(symbol)
What does actually need to change in the market data so that something is returned in that function?

Thank you very much in advance,

Unai
author: unaiasegi

comments.body:
Hi!

In general, WS is more about real-time. 
You have two types of data:

1. real-time fills + real-time orderbooks ‚Äì¬†this is the first-order data that is used to calculate everything else
2. second-order data (tickers and ohlcvs) that is calculated from first-order data

Changes on first-order data (1) are delivered as soon as the exchange can.

It takes time for the exchange to calculate the statistical second-order data, but you can also calculate it on your own (you don't have to wait for the exchange to do it for you). 

How frequently to deliver the changes on second-order data (2) ‚Äì depends on the exchange. Some exchanges will update you in regular intervals (like once or a few times every second), others will update the ticker more frequently. Some exchanges will send you delayed second-order data since it is not considered _"important"_ for a real-time trading operation.

You should not rely on the speed of tickers or OHLCVs if you wish to stay as close to real-time as possible.

Let us know if that does not answer your question.

It does, thank you very much.

Unai

body: watchCreateOrder/watchCancelOrder is currently not supported for any exchange in ccxt pro?
author: wunderb1t

comments.body:
Most of the the exchanges don't have the means for placing the orders over WS, so it boils down to `createOrder` + `watchOrders`. In other words, you should be able to watch your orders while they're being created (which is what you want as far as I understand).
Let us know if that does not answer your question.
