title: Possible bug in commonCurrencies
body:
- OS: *
- Programming Language version: python
- CCXT version: 1.18.593-643
- Exchange: bitfinex
- Method: commonCurrencies

Hi, I'm using the commonCurrencies in my code for margin trading on bitfinex. It think this has been broken in a recent release. You can see this the following way:

if I do:
```Python
print(str(ccxt.bitfinex.commonCurrencies.items()))
```
I get:
```
dict_items([('XBT', 'BTC'), ('BCC', 'BCH'), ('DRK', 'DASH'), ('BCHABC', 'BCH'), ('BCHSV', 'BSV')])
```

While this is not the list found in the bitfinex.py.. My guess is that this is Kraken (?)

Or am I making a mistake somewhere?
author: jdieks

comments.body:
> Or am I making a mistake somewhere?

Yes, the `commonCurrencies` is not a list of currencies for the exchange, it's a list of substitutions for for all the exchanges, which is inherited from the Exchange base class.

If you want to get a list of currencies for an exchange, you should check `.currencies` instead of `.commonCurrencies` after calling `load_markets()`:

```Python
from pprint import pprint
import ccxt
exchange = ccxt.bitfinex({ 'enableRateLimit': True })
exchange.load_markets()
pprint(exchange.currencies)
```

Let us know if that doesn't answer the question )

Hi Kroitor,

Thanks for the reply. Yes, I see how it works now.
In an older version I used the ccxt.bitfinex.commonCurrencies.items() list to convert the ccxt commoncurrencies back to the ones that the api of bitfinex wants to see (e.g. BCH:BAB).

But I see that I can indeed do exactly the same thing with the currencies command. Thanks for the help.

Have a good night.

title: suggestion: add parseMyTrade method
body: There are a number of places where the shape of the data for `fetchMyTrades` differs sufficiently from the result of `fetchTrades`.  We could consider adding `parseMyTrade(s)` which in the base class could just delegate to the existing method(s).
author: npomfret

comments.body: Not sure how we could do this, since in the base class the methods are defined as stubs that throw `NotImplemented`. We could do a try, catch in the base class but that is kinda ugly. Ideally exchanges should have a single trade object...
Where are the stubs defined?

> Ideally exchanges should have a single trade object...

I agree with this.

> We could consider adding parseMyTrade(s) which in the base class could just delegate to the existing method(s).

Tbh, I don't think that adding parseMyTrade is good in the long-term. I think if we keep it the way it is, the exchanges will ultimately have to normalize their response types... I don't think we should relax the standard, because that boils down to no standard. 

Lmk your thoughts.

It's a subtle one. If we were doing this with objects I'd maybe have a `Trade` object which is extended by a `MyTrade` object (containing order id, fee etc).  They are related of course, but they are definitely different.  No exchange (I think) publishes the order id associated to a trade in their public trade feed.  But every exchange (I think), does provide the order id in the private trade feed. And occasionally, exchanges have, for no obvious reason, a completely different set of fields for these two objects that more or less represent the same thing.

>No exchange (I think) publishes the order id associated to a trade in their public trade feed. 

> But every exchange (I think), does provide the order id in the private trade feed.

I think you're wrong on both claims ) At least, I know of many exchanges who actually do the former and the latter, and in a distributed environment most of the info is public, so in general I would rather encourage unification of the structure.

> If we were doing this with objects I'd maybe have a Trade object which is extended by a MyTrade object (containing order id, fee etc).

I am approaching this from the opposite direction, in other words, suppose there is already a Trade class (that is our unified structure) and that trade class contains all the commonly used fields of a personal trade. However for public trades some of those fields are empty or null. That is basically the same story, one abstraction wraps another, but thinking in terms of plain json structures makes everything a lot more portable. Ideally, the code that would work with those structures will be a lot easier to write and manage. 

> And occasionally, exchanges have, for no obvious reason, a completely different set of fields for these two objects that more or less represent the same thing.

We're far from the ideal now, of course, therefore we have to keep some workarounds there, but in this case i think encouraging unification and standardization is better than relaxing the rules in the long-term. It may be a bit more convenient now to code parseTrade and parseMyTrade separately, but this short-term convenience can cost us more time on coding the entire zoo of parsers in the long run.

Nothing really forbids what you say, and, in fact, as you know, we already have parseTrade and parseMyTrade in the master branch with some exchanges, but this is probably not the best design decision strategically.

title: Transaction fees ‚Äì¬†net or gross?
body: Should the amount in the transfer (for withdrawals) be equal to the amount the receiver receives (ie net of withdrawal fees), or should it be the gross amount (so the receiver should receive `amount - fee.cost`)?
author: npomfret

comments.body:
Regardless of what the answer is, there may be a bug in Poloniex.  In this XRP withdrawal example the data is:

```
amount: 501.10000007,
info:
      { fee: '0.15000000',
        type: 'withdrawal',
        amount: '501.25000007',
        status:
         'COMPLETE: 1419A5E5D66AE500DE8CF7BB1255B954C71C17F21E07CB9D031C9ABC2FB317ED',
        address: 'rK1MAqAbK6S64rQZCcfQnWSR9cCvotSC5u',
```

But the receiver received `501.25`... so more was receive than was sent.

@npomfret 

> be equal to the amount the receiver receives (ie net of withdrawal fees)

The balance of the sender should be deduced by the `amount` and by the `fee` separately (as I think of it, but there may be other opinions), and the receiver should receive just the `amount`.

Is there a problem with all your withdrawals or for this particular one? It looks like a very old one (Jan 2018), and the arithmetics for fees may have changed over time. We will review Poloniex again though.

> Is there a problem with all your withdrawals or for this particular one?

Good question.  Poloniex looks inconsistent.  Here's a more recent one:

```
{
  "fee": "0.01000000",
  "type": "withdrawal",
  "amount": "10.44581161",
  "status": "COMPLETE: 0x16ec0102bcade18fe5e7c4b5e0b03562c5be91e2b6a926738215bbd75c89c0b0",
  "address": "0x15c9f7Cfcee1696FaF58528E8aBd740908b8e830",
  "currency": "ETH",,...
```

And the _correct_ amount (10.43581161) was received.  I've looked a load more examples and other than rounding issues I can't find another one that looks wrong.
@npomfret thx for reporting back! Really appreciate your comments, always very helpful!

@kroitor  I just wanted to check what the net/gross fee *should* be for withdrawals, as I think we still have inconsistencies.

So we have a withdrawal amount and a fee...

Does the user's balance reduce by `amount + fee`?  Which implies the destination receives the `amount`.

Or, does the user's balance reduce by `amount`?  Which implied the destination receives the `amount - fee`.

I thought it was the latter (but from what i've checked today, the former appears to be more common)

> Does the user's balance reduce by `amount + fee`? Which implies the destination receives the `amount`.
> Or, does the user's balance reduce by `amount`? Which implied the destination receives the `amount - fee`.
> I thought it was the latter (but from what i've checked today, the former appears to be more common)

This is not fully unified yet. Some exchanges will deduce the fee from the amount, other exchanges will charge the fee on top of the amount. I think it's better to make transaction `amount` reflect the value that will be deposited on the receiving side ‚Äì that helps match withdrawals with deposits across exchanges (the former scenario that is more common). However, in case of exmo and poloniex we deduce the fee cost from the amount, that depends on which specific value is returned from the exchange in the `amount` field.

Ok thanks

So we need to subtract the fee cost from the amount for btcmarkets too then.  Currently they don't add up.

title: Supporting multiple fees in different currencies in trades
author: npomfret

comments.body:
> Is this a common model?

Yes, so far. It is not documented yet, because it's still "in the works".
The current model is to have either `fee` or `fees`, the latter being an array.

> Or could we have a standard fee, which can be an array of objects or a single object? Or always have fees as an array, typically an array of length one except in cases like that above?

In general, a typecheck is harder than a key lookup, I think. And if we switch to an array ‚Äì that might break the backward-compatibility... So, we need to consider it carefully... @xpl, @tankakatan what's your opinion on this?

> And if we switch to an array ‚Äì that might break the backward-compatibility...

That will surely break all of the people's current code. But. I personally consider it a headache, having in some cases `fee` (object) and in some cases `fees` (array), because everywhere I need to consider fees, I currently need to write a coercion code that normalizes that to a general form (array):

```javascript
const fees = trade.fees || [trade.fee]
```

Leaving just `fees` alone would certainly be a right thing to do. What we can do is to perform a smooth transition, outputting both `fee` (in case of a single fee, for backward compatibility) *and* `fees` (always, for future code). Then remove any mentions of `fee` from the documentation, and explicitly announce that `fee` will be removed soon. Then finally remove `fee` some months later, raising the major version number.

> What we can do is to perform a smooth transition

Yeah, I think it's the way to go. We should start adding `fees` everywhere.
`fees` are being provided now in supported exchanges. closing this topic for now.

title: exmo trade parse 'injects' a fee
body:
`fetchMyTrades` in exmo injects a fee into the parsed trade based on the metadata of the class (the json response from the exchange doesn't include the fee).

Is this a sensible, or normal thing to do?  Feels like it could give invalid results, say if they change their fees, or the user has a different fee structure to that which is specified in ccxt.
author: npomfret

comments.body:
thanks you so much ,but I'm jsut a rookie ! so i'm kepping quiet right now ! but I believe in a short time .
I will definitely make my contribution !

> Is this a sensible, or normal thing to do?

We previously fetched their fees programmatically from their website, by parsing their web front-end output. But since then it got broken (those requests are now quickly getting banned), that forced us to switch to hard-coded fees, so...

> Feels like it could give invalid results, say if they change their fees, or the user has a different fee structure to that which is specified in ccxt

...yes, it can happen. But I suppose they don't have fees in their API output because they don't plan to change them anytime soon. So they kinda encourage their users to use hard-coded values.

title: question about exchange class inheritance
body:
I've been trying to add some API calls to a the bluetrade class but have run into some problems due to the fact it inherits from bittrex.

I want to mix v3 api calls into the current implementation.  The problem is that currently there is a version set, so all urls get a `v2` added to their path.

If I remove the version and add `v2/` to each api path then the super class fails because the method names are wrong.

@kroitor do you have any suggestions for a _nice_ way to work around this problem?
author: npomfret

comments.body:
I really struggled with bleutrade.  I've bodged a new api call to a v3 endpoint just in an attempt to get something working.  I ended up giving bleutrade it's own sign method... hope I didn't break anything.  

I really don't think the inheritance pattern is helpful in the case.  The sign method in bittrex is particularly complicated.  I think someone has gone to a lot of effort in order to avoid a bit of duplication.  But the result is a bit of a tangled mess.  IMO this is a case where more code and a little duplication (i.e. one `sign` method per class) is a better way forward because the current solution is hard (for me) to understand.  For example, it took me about an hour to figure out that the http method name (get/post) was being inserted in to the url path.
I totally agree with all of the above, it has to be decoupled and we shouldn't mix them. Closing this for now until we have further updates on Bleutrade...

title: Are API keys and secret credentials safe?
body:
Hello, 
is there any guarantee that secret keys are not sent elsewhere? Can that be done?
Could someone merge changes to ccxt that take API keys and secrets and store somewhere on their cloud so they could have access to your account?

These library seems such a nice idea and work but taking into account the nature of the data (money exchanges) I'm not really sure how we, as developers, can be sure about giving our API secrets without thinking about it.
author: ibesora

comments.body:
Hi!

> is there any guarantee that secret keys are not sent elsewhere?

Yes, this is guaranteed implicitly in the following way: this project is open-source, so the developer can read the code and see what's happening with the secret key within the library ‚Äì¬†and from there any sufficiently-experienced developer can see that CCXT is absolutely honest and transparent. The secret keys are not sent anywhere, and this is the security policy that is implemented throughout this library. 

This library has been reviewed by a few thousands of developers, among them are very highly skilled coders and they haven't found anything suspicious. CCXT has 10k stars, more than 2k clones, more than 7 hundred dependent projects, etc ‚Äì¬†if there was an obvious hole, someone would shout about it. Moreover, the independent devs have helped build it out extensively themselves. This lib has more than 3 hundred people from all over the world involved in the development of it. The guarantee is provided by the common people based on the open nature of this project )

However, formally, this library is licensed under MIT which states "no guarantee, use as is at your own risk". So, for most open-source projects, the guarantee you want should be provided to you by yourself first and foremost. In other words, don't install and run the code that you haven't checked for security personally, because other people may be lying to you. Including me now.

> Can that be done?

Yes, if someone substitutes your CCXT installation with a hacked version of it ‚Äì¬†your keys may be stolen. But if that happens, it is not a failure of CCXT, but more a failure of your security administration. Any code can be hacked. Your operating system can be hacked in the same way. So, it's always possible, and the possibility depends on your own security policies more than on the CCXT codebase.

> Could someone merge changes to ccxt that take API keys and secrets and store somewhere on their cloud so they could have access to your account?

The right to merge is very restricted, only three devs from the core team have that permission, and all three are the initial authors of the project. We review each and every PR for security. We don't do massive-merges blindly and we are very picky. So far, we haven't merged anything that would compromise the security, and we've managed to keep the reputation clean for more than 2 years. 

At some point we can try to add the cheating code that will take your keypair and will send it to us. And then wait till you download the update. However, there's more than 700 independent people on Github (apart from the rest) who constantly watch each and every edit we make, so, even if we attempt a trick like that ‚Äì¬†it won't go unnoticed. Doing so will immediately ruin everything we've been fighting for. 

So, in order to get such a guarantee for yourself and to completely protect from that ‚Äì just become a watcher. So, ultimately, it's up to you how much trust or distrust you want to put into it. You can check each update for security to ensure that your security isn't compromised. And if you don't check bits of your software regularly ‚Äì¬†your security is already compromised.

Hope that answers the question ) Let us know if not)

title: Question about "cost" in different orders
body:
OS: Windows 10 Programming Language version: Node.js CCXT version: #465 Exchange: All Exchanges Node.js 11.9.0 installed Method: createOrder, cancelOrder, fetchOrder, fetchClosedOrders Hello! I have a general question about the below methods when implementing correct mathematics: ```javascript createOrder(exchange, exchangename, symbol, type, side, amount, price); cancelOrder(exchange, exchangename, id, symbol); fetchOrder(exchange, exchangename, id, symbol); fetchClosedOrders(symbol, since) ``` The question is about the "cost" response like below: ```javascript { 'id': '12345-67890:09876/54321', // string 'datetime': '2017-08-17 12:42:48.000', // ISO8601 datetime of 'timestamp' with milliseconds 'timestamp': 1502962946216, // order placing/opening Unix timestamp in milliseconds 'lastTradeTimestamp': 1502962956216, // Unix timestamp of the most recent trade on this order 'status': 'open', // 'open', 'closed', 'canceled' 'symbol': 'ETH/BTC', // symbol 'type': 'limit', // 'market', 'limit' 'side': 'buy', // 'buy', 'sell' 'price': 0.06917684, // float price in quote currency 'amount': 1.5, // ordered amount of base currency 'filled': 1.1, // filled amount of base currency 'remaining': 0.4, // remaining amount to fill 'cost': 0.076094524, // 'filled' * 'price' (filling price used where available) 'trades': [ ... ], // a list of order trades/executions 'fee': { // fee info, if available 'currency': 'BTC', // which currency the fee is (usually quote) 'cost': 0.0009, // the fee amount in that currency 'rate': 0.002, // the fee rate (if available) }, 'info': { ... }, // the original unparsed order structure as is } ``` As seen in above example, it shows: "0.076094524" (filled' * 'price) What I wonder in this example: **- We do Buy ETH for BTC.** I wonder if it is true that we actually then do have Exactly **0.076094524 ETH** in the account or do one need to take any fee into considiration (0.2%(0.002)). I mean, if the trade ends here. Would it be safe to for example then Sell Exactly or Maximum **0.076094524 ETH** to another currency? (Taking correct rounding into acccount) I wonder if this is safe to do this for all the methods:
**createOrder, cancelOrder, fetchOrder, fetchClosedOrders** ? Thank you
author: jackpotcityco

comments.body:
@jackpotcityco first, let me please correct your formulation to prevent a possible confusion. When we talk about exchange orders/trades, we assume that we want to buy or sell an `amount` (that may or may not be `filled`) of base asset (i.e. ETH in your case) at `price` (and for `cost`) in the quote asset (i.e. BTC in your case).

It means that in your example 0.076094524 is the value of BTC that you pay for 1.1 ETH and 0.0009 BTC is the fee that you pay on top of it.

Now regarding your question (if i get it right). Let us assume that the fee currency is the same as the one you want to earn in via your order. You now want to know whether the fee will reduce your earning or not. If i understood you correctly, then the answer is **yes** ‚Äì a value of `fee.cost` will always be commissioned from your account corresponding to `fee.currency` regardless the order `side`.

To clarify the above let's run through all possible combinations:

* after your _buy_ order of X ETH at price of Y BTC with fee of Z BTC filled, your ETH balance will be _replenished_ by X while your BTC balance will be _diminished_ by (Y*X)+Z

* after your _sell_ order of X ETH at price of Y BTC with fee of Z BTC filled, your ETH balance will be _diminished_ by X while your BTC balance will be _replenished_ by (Y*X)-Z

* after your _buy_ order of X ETH at price of Y BTC with fee of Z ETH filled, your ETH balance will be _replenished_ by X-Z while your BTC balance will be _diminished_ by Y*X

* after your _sell_ order of X ETH at price of Y BTC with fee of Z ETH filled, your ETH balance will be _diminished_ by X+Z while your BTC balance will be _replenished_ by Y*X

The above rules are true for all markets at all exchanges and will be applied to all methods that you have mentioned
> createOrder, cancelOrder, fetchOrder, fetchClosedOrders

Does this answer your question?
@jackpotcityco let us know if you have further questions.

OS: Windows 10

Hello!

I have a question about the **"percentage"** parameter when requesting:
```javascript
const markets = await exchange.loadMarkets()
```
I could see that for some exchanges **"percentage"** is present in the returnd JSON and other exchanges not. If looking at the below example binance has **"percentage"** and coinex doesn't.

For coinex, this information is shown. Then I wonder how to think. Is this **"percentage"** or not. I am bit confused there?
**"taker":0.001,"maker":0.001**

**JSON for binance and coinex:**
**coinex**
"BBN/BCH":{"limits":{"amount":{"min":1},"price":{"min":1e-8}},"precision":{"amount":8,"price":8},"taker":0.001,"maker":0.001,"id":"BBNBCH","symbol":"BBN/BCH","base":"BBN","quote":"BCH","baseId":"BBN","quoteId":"BCH","active":true

**binance**
"ETH/BTC":{"limits":{"amount":{"min":0.001,"max":100000},"price":{},"cost":{"min":0.001}},"precision":{"base":8,"quote":8,"amount":3,"price":6},"tierBased":false,"percentage":true,"taker":0.001,"maker":0.001,"id":"ETHBTC","symbol":"ETH/BTC","base":"ETH","quote":"BTC","baseId":"ETH","quoteId":"BTC"
author: jackpotcityco

comments.body:
> Then I wonder how to think. Is this "percentage" or not. I am bit confused there?

In general, it's always a percentage, unless percentage is defined (not undefined) and has a value of `false`. If you don't see it defined anywhere or it has a value different from `false`, then it's true. 

So, in this particular case you can assume percentages safely.

Let us know if that doesn't answer the question. We will unify this aspect with coinex and other exchanges, thx for reporting!

> In general, it's always a percentage, unless percentage is defined (not undefined) and has a value of false. If you don't see it defined anywhere or it has a value different from false, then it's true.

Thank you for the clarification. I will go with percentages then. 
That is great to find something that can help out for the library!

title: questions about order structure
body:
Regarding the order `status`, the docs say:

>     'status':     'open',         // 'open', 'closed', 'canceled'

If an order is partially filled and then cancelled, what should the status be?

Regarding the `cost`:

>     'cost':        0.076094524,   // 'filled' * 'price' (filling price used where available)

If the _filling price_ isn't available, should this field be left blank?  (I think it should)
author: npomfret

comments.body:
> If an order is partially filled and then cancelled, what should the status be?

- `status == 'canceled'`
- `filled > 0`
- `filled < amount`

> If the filling price isn't available, should this field be left blank? (I think it should)

The problem is 3/4 of exchanges do not actually return the filling price or assume filling price = limit price in their engines. So, we only fill it if
- the exchange provides the actual cost in the response, so we don't have to calculate it
- the exchange doesn't provide the actual cost from the API we use `filled * price` with the most accurate price available:
  - if the exchange specifies the filling price ‚Äì we use that
  - otherwise we use the limit price from the exchange response

Let us know if that doesn't answer your questions.

Thanks.

> ... otherwise we use the limit price from the exchange response 

Do you mean the limit price the original order was set at? If so this could result in an inaccurate figure, no?

> Do you mean the limit price the original order was set at? 

Nope, when you query an order by id ‚Äì¬†you don't specify the price of the original order.
Say, you `fetchOrder (someId)`. You get an order response from the exchange.

It could look like

```JavaScript
    ...
    amount: 5,
    price: 2, // this is the limit price, but we take it from this response, not from the original order
    cost: 10,  // ‚Üê this can be missing
    filling_price: 2, // ‚Üê this can be missing
    ...
```

‚Üë If the cost and the filling price are both missing, then the only thing we can take for the cost is `amount * price`. In most cases exchanges won't provide any further detail. Otherwise you just don't rely on the order cost at all, and use `fetchMyTrades` or `fetchOrderTrades` to get the actual executed fills and filling prices/costs for your trades per order.

In other words, we don't use the params of the original order and we only use the values from the response, if those values are provided by the exchange. There's one special case that involves the `orders` cache, but very few exchanges actually implement it.

> If so this could result in an inaccurate figure, no?

Yes, however, the figure will be as accurate as you can get from that endpoint of that exchange.
Ok. For what it's worth I think leaving it blank, rather than potentially providing an inaccurate figure, is best.

> For what it's worth I think leaving it blank, rather than potentially providing an inaccurate figure, is best.

I totally agree on this, so, if you notice a lying cost somewhere, please do let us know.

title: Question about: enableRateLimit': true
author: jackpotcityco

comments.body:
> Should I in my code use: 'enableRateLimit': true ?

Depends on what your code does, of course. We can't answer what your code should do )

> enableRateLimit': false (Takes 1 second) This is not a good id√©a to do?

It's ok as long as you know what you're doing.

> Assume that I only would run this code once every minute which would be clearly below 1200 requests/minute. 

In that case, the above idea is ok.

> Is there Also a limit as the manual says to ONLY do 1 HTTP requests per 2000 milliseconds as this also can get ones IP banned?

No, there is no such specific limit defined in the Manual. The Manual says that there's a default value for the rate limit, but the actual threshold value depends on the exchange in question. Each exchange has its own rate-limits. So, you should treat that value in a flexible way. The Manual also says that the default will be sub-optimal, so the user should tweak those values for the needs of his application.

Let us know if that doesn't answer the question.

It was the perfect answer. It was a good confirmation to be on the sure side.
So it is a default value and I should tweak it according the the different exchanges  and usecases then.

Thank you for your help!

title: create standard objects
body:
The list of standardised fields is growing quickly. This issue serves to discuss how we should go about populating all fields in the standard structure. 

`parseX` functions could return

```
return this.deepExtend (defaultTransaction, {
    'amount': 12.3,
})
```

* is there any reason to *not* change to this style?
* where should we store standard objects?

a standard object is the just the expected object but with `undefined`/ empty container type for all it's fields.
author: frosty00

comments.body: another benefit to doing this is that if we decide to change X structure it should change everywhere

> * is there any reason to _not_ change to this style?

To me this is a strong argument for changing to this style:

> another benefit to doing this is that if we decide to change X structure it should change everywhere

I agree, this is more convenient in regard of new fields. So, +1 for **ease of adding new fields and massive updates**. And in terms of automated testing, it simplifies consistency on the user end, so +1 for **consistency**. 

However, I also see these reasons not to do this:

- -1 for **speed**: If we do `return this.deepExtend (defaultTransaction, { 'amount': 12.3 })` from inside each object being parsed, then, we're introducing a loop into every call to a `parse*` method, which makes all the call chain much slower and, what's more important, that effectively raises the requirements for ram, especially if you're running, say, a few dozens of exchange classes on each node of your system.
- -1 for **completeness**: To me making those declarations of unified structures implicit means more errors in contributions or more incomplete contributions ‚Äì if it is not required to list them all out and list all their values, including the undefined ones, then not enough attention might be paid to it and then the devs will tend to skip as much as they can defaulting to the predefined values, and we don't really want to have a lot of "partial implementations", our goal is to be as complete as possible. I would rather restrict those rules even further to stop producing new incomplete implementations.
- -1 for **ease of maintenance**: A plain structure is easier for keeping in mind, understanding and editing if all of it is on the same screen. Despite that this might seem like an insignificant point, it becomes really critical when it comes to merging code written by a lot of different people.

As an alternative solution, we could also add a quick script to check and validate those structures for consistency and even highlight them in transpile-time, before actually transpiling them. We would still use regexes to do massive adjustments to the code for updates, but doing consistency in transpile-time would help save the mem and speed.

title: Gemini fetchMyTrades requires symbol
body:
Most exchanges use fetchMyTrades to obtain trades for all symbols. Gemini does not: a symbol is required. fetchMyTrades ought to behave uniformly for all exchanges.

I've updated Gemini.js in two ways. First, the current fetchMyTrades has become fetchMyTradesBySymbol. I'm reasonably certain that is not a naming convention that will stay but its my initial suggestion. Second, I've created a new fetchMyTrades that iterates over the symbols at Gemini and calls fetchMyTradesBySymbol for each one. 

This may not be ideal behavior as it will send in a number of REST API requests. I looked at the Gemini API specs here. It does indicate to provide a symbol but I have not tested out whether it works without one or not. I do have my own Gemini api js library so I can test it independently, but I may not be able to get to it too soon. 

@kroitor -- please advise if I ought to be raising issues for any/every potential pull request. I have a few more as I'm trying to get uniform access (esp via fetchMyTrades) for the exchanges that I use. Until I hear otherwise, I will raise as an issue first.
author: gRittyKitty

comments.body:
Hi @gRittyKitty,

> Most exchanges use fetchMyTrades to obtain trades for all symbols. Gemini does not: a symbol is required. fetchMyTrades ought to behave uniformly for all exchanges.

Nope, sometimes `fetchMyTrades` requires a symbol. If you want to write code that is exchange agnostic you need to provide a symbol. 

>  Second, I've created a new fetchMyTrades that iterates over the symbols at Gemini and calls fetchMyTradesBySymbol for each one.

This is not allowed in the library because it breaks the rule "one request per unified method". The reason for this rule is that it allows people to write async python code that can do other stuff while it is waiting. Having 100 calls in one method would mean python would have to evaluate them all synchronously.

Thanks, @frosty00. Appreciate the explanation of the async. I won't do the pull request.
Is there a way to tell programmatically if fetchMyTrades needs a symbol or gets data for all symbols?

> Thx @frosty00 !
> 
> @gRittyKitty
> 
> > Is there a way to tell programmatically if fetchMyTrades needs a symbol or gets data for all symbols?
> 
> We don't have a full description of the schema yet, but we will have it hopefully soon. In the meantime the method will throw an `ArgumentsRequired` exception if it needs a symbol, so, you can catch that exception and try with a symbol then.
> 
> ```js
> let trades = undefined
> try {
>     trades = await exchange.fetchMyTrades ()
> } catch (e) {
>     if (e instanceof ccxt.ArgumentsRequired) {
>         trades = await exchange.fetchMyTrades (symbol)
>     } else {
>         throw e
>     }
> }
> ```
> 
> Hope this helps.

come on mate, we do not have problem how to handle errors...we want to fetch all them at the same time not by symbol param? any solution

title: fetchMinOrderAmounts is used in wrong location
body:
You scrape the minOrderAmounts nicely fro kraken, but they are per currency, not per pair. As such I would expect them to be populated when I do a call to `fetchCurrencies`, and not in `fetchMarkets`.

- Programming Language version: es6
- CCXT version: 1.18.190
- Exchange: kraken
- Method: fetchMarkets
author: Morriz

comments.body:
@Morriz min order amount is actually a property of a market (pair), if you think of it, this is more flexible than having min order amount per currency. 

Some exchanges have min order amount that varies for the same currency in different pairs. It is really a per-market property, not a per-currency property, therefore we load it for markets, not for currencies.

You can't trade (place orders) with a single currency ‚Äì orders are not compatible with single currencies logically. You can trade with a pair of currencies only. In that pair you order one currency for a promise to pay another currency. So min order amount is always related to one currency in a pair of currencies (logically). And putting min order amount into the currency structure would be a structural mistake that would allow to handle Kraken, but no other exchange. 

We choose to go another way and we have min order amount in the market structure, which covers Kraken as well as the other exchanges, so it's more generic and versatile to have that property in the market structure, not in the currency structure. 

Hope this answers your question, let me know if not.
understood...thanks for another swift reply :)

title: Question: Is it possible to add a request to the top of the rateLimiter-Queue?
body: I currently have a ton of rest requests to download historic data and I would like to add some other requests at the top of the rateLimiter-queue. Is this supported atm? or is there an easy way to achieve such a thing?
author: tommuhm

comments.body:
Adding requests on top means sending them out of order, right? So, you want an out-of-band message, that essentially means that you want to send your requests immediately, without waiting for the queue to flush first. The existing built-in rate-limiter implementation is flexible enough for that (we use the tokenBucket algorithm), but it currently has no unified interface for controlling that specific behavior, it's a work in progress. 

However, there are possible workarounds:

- override the `.throttle()` method by implementing your rate-limiting logic
- set `enableRateLimit = false` before issuing an oob message, then set it back to `true` immediately after (this effectively overrides the waiting queue, but the downside is that it disables the rate-limiter, so your oob message won't always wait for the next nonce)
- use a second instance of the exchange class with a single rate-limiter logic shared between the two instances

Anyways, currently it doesn't have a unified convenient option for oob requests, so it implies adding some custom code on user side. We'll do our best to add more flexibility to it asap. Let me know if that does not answer the question. Thx!

> When doing the fetch_tickers() function, the bid/ask are empty.

That is documented ‚Äì not all of exchanges will return all the info. Most of them will return a subset of the documented fields (others will be empty, if not provided by the exchange in question). Some of them, like Coinfalcon, will provide just the bare minimum (24hr volume data). So, in general, it's normal with some exchanges, and if the exchange does not provide the data you want ‚Äì we can't really invent it for you from nothing (that wouldn't be fair to you in the first place). title: askVolume and betVolume for exchanges
body:
Hello,

I only get the askVolume and betVolume for Binance when using the price ticker method is this normal? If yes is there a way to get these values? 
(I used the exchanges: binance, bittrex, bitfinexcrex24, hitbtc and kraken.)

Thank you in advance!
author: AlgoQ

comments.body: `askVolume` and `bidVolume` will only be defined if the underlying exchange provides that information from the ticker endpoint. If not ‚Äì¬†those will be undefined. Not all exchanges provide that information in the ticker call. So, yes, that is normal. If you want the bid and ask volume for each exchange universally ‚Äì¬†you should call fetchOrderBook and get values from there.

title: Python ujson has much better performance than the std json
body:
Is it possible to use ujson(or yajl) instead of the std json in CCXT?
Thanks!
author: ngugcx

comments.body:
> Is it possible to use ujson(or yajl) instead of the std json in CCXT?

Sure!

Let me know if this does not answer your question:

```Python
import ccxt
import ujson
exchange = ccxt.binance({
    'parse_json': ujson.loads
})
print(exchange.fetchTicker('ETH/BTC'))
```

Thanks! This works for normal exchanges.
Exchanges like cryptopia whose responses need to be normalized  before json-parsing will fail.

> Exchanges like cryptopia whose responses need to be normalized before json-parsing will fail.

Yep, but you can do a cryptopia-specific override in the same manner and fix the json before calling `loads`, basically, as long as you can override everything ‚Äì¬†this isn't an issue in CCXT )

title: Is there an api abstraction for FUTURE?
body:
The ccxt SPOT api abstraction is awesome!
There are more and more exchanges which support FUTURE.
Is there a plan to support FUTURE?
author: ngugcx

comments.body:
> Is there a plan to support FUTURE?

Currently, we implement implicit methods around all http endpoints, including the ones for trading futures contracts. However, you're right, it's not unified yet, it's a work in progress. We have plans to  unify the following aspects:
- margin trading (including leveraged positions)
- futures trading
- perpetual contracts

Let us know if that does not answer your question.

title: Is there any modifyOrder method?
body:
Hi, 

There are openOrder , cancelOrder, but I can't find a modifyOrder method..

Is there any modifyOrder in CCXT?

Regards
author: Gennttii

comments.body:
> Is there any modifyOrder in CCXT?

Yes, it is called `editOrder` and we use the endpoint from the exchange, if the exchange in question provides such an endpoint for editing orders, and if not ‚Äì¬†it falls back to a default implementation in the base class that will do two calls sequentially ‚Äì¬†cancel the first order and create a new one. Let us know if that does not answer your question.

title: fetch_ohlcv determine limit per exchange
body:
- OS: LInux
- Programming Language version: python3.7
- CCXT version: '1.17.363'
- Exchange: multiple
- Method: fetch_ohlcv


when using the following code, i get different results depending on the exchange.
I understand that it's exchange-dependent what the upper limit is, but is there a way to know what this limit is (and the default parameter) for the exchange i'm currently querying before making the first call?

```
import ccxt
from datetime import datetime, timezone
start = datetime.strptime("01.10.2018", "%d.%m.%Y").replace(
           tzinfo=timezone.utc).timestamp()
timeframe='1h'
limit=None
binance = ccxt.binance()
hitbtc = ccxt.hitbtc2()
kraken = ccxt.kraken()

hitbtc_ohlcv = hitbtc.fetch_ohlcv("ETH/BTC", timeframe=timeframe, since=int(start*1000), limit=limit)
binance_ohlcv = binance.fetch_ohlcv("ETH/BTC", timeframe=timeframe, since=int(start*1000), limit=limit)
kraken_ohlcv = kraken.fetch_ohlcv("ETH/BTC", timeframe=timeframe, since=int(start*1000), limit=limit)

print(f"hitbtc: {len(hitbtc_ohlcv)}")
print(f"binance: {len(binance_ohlcv)}")
print(f"kraken: {len(kraken_ohlcv)}")

```

Output
```
hitbtc: 1000
binance: 1000
kraken: 720
```

in addition to that, the default seems to vary - using `limit=None` in the above code returns a different output for hitbtc:
```
hitbtc: 100
binance: 500
kraken: 720
```
author: xmatthias

comments.body:
> is there a way to know what this limit is (and the default parameter) for the exchange i'm currently querying before making the first call?

Currently ‚Äì¬†without looking into the code ‚Äì¬†nope, unfortunately, it's just one of the aspects that is not unified completely yet, but we surely want to unify it as well. We have plans on proposing a much better approach to pagination (that will cover your request), hopefully, soon. 

Let us know if that does not answer your question, feel free to reopen it if needed.

title: *ToPrecision methods return strings
body:
Need add parseFloat() before return.
Thanks!

OS: OS X
Programming Language version:
CCXT version: 1.17.488
Exchange: JavaScript
Method: priceToPrecision, amountToPrecision, costToPrecision, feeToPrecision
author: ErickMarlo

comments.body:
Those methods are designed to return string-based representations of numbers, that is because some exchanges will require numbers as strings for precision reasons...

Therefore `parseFloat` is not added *inside* those methods (may be excessive in some cases) and if you want to get floats ‚Äì¬†you just add `parseFloat` on the *outside* in userland:

```
n = e[x].amountToPrecision(ss,1.2345678901234567890111) 
console.log("amountToPrecision", typeof n,n)
```

‚Üì

```
n = parseFloat (e[x].amountToPrecision(ss,1.2345678901234567890111))
console.log("amountToPrecision", typeof n,n)
```

Hope this answers your questions, let us know if not.

title: bittrex fetchDeposits returns no timestamp and datetime
body:
- OS: Linux
- Programming Language version: PHP
- CCXT version: 1.17.421
- Exchange: bittrex
- Method: fetchDeposit

The only timestamp returned from the exchnage for withdrawals is in the 'LastUpdated' field. This should probably be used for the timestamp and datetime. The 'Opened' field that is used for Withdrawals is not available when fetching deposits
author: WoK-E

comments.body:
> The only timestamp returned from the exchnage for withdrawals is in the 'LastUpdated' field. This should probably be used for the timestamp and datetime. 

Nope, unfortunately, we can't set that timestamp there, because it literally means the last updated timestamp, therefore it is in the transaction structure, in the `updated` field. We don't invent values where the exchange in question does not provide them. You can add that logic to your code in userland on client-side, namely, *"consider `updated` for Bittrex deposits a `timestamp`"*. But, unfortunately, this may not play well for all users equally. The other signifcant reason behind it is that the LastUpdated field can change, which should not happen to a unified `timestamp` (it should always be fixed, unchanging, if set).

> The 'Opened' field that is used for Withdrawals is not available when fetching deposits

Right, this is by design again, same reasoning basically. Anyways, they don't support any date-based pagination for deposits and withdrawals whatsoever.

Does the above answer your question? )

Yes, it does answer the question, and I understand the reasoning. I will; be closing the issue.

The reason I use 'LastUpdated' is because this is when the exchange gets enough confirmations, in order to consider the deposit valid, and stops updating the record. The other (selfish) reason is because I want to minimize the ccxt classes I extend in order to provide such extra logic and functionality :)

Thanks for the prompt response, and thanks for this great library!

title: Making loadMarkets/fetchMarkets accept a marketid as a parameter, to speed things up
body:
Can the loadmarkets/fetchmarkets function be modified as to accept a parameter indicating what market are we interested in? It could even be left as an optional parameter, which if omitted would simply make the functions behave as they do now and get all the markets.

This is an efficiency feature, as there are big exchanges which do have HUNDREDS of markets, and reading all of them when you just need a single market is time consuming without any reason. I don't know if other coders are doing like me, but I rarely need these infos for more than two markets in a specific moment, and loading 600+ markets (for example on livecoin there are 666 markets) when you need one of them is slow...
author: ShoresOfNowhere

comments.body: @ShoresOfNowhere in most cases loading 600 markets takes exactly the same amount of https requests as loading just one market. That is because all of them are loaded in a signle call to the endpoint responsible for the list of markets, and you can't really choose or specify that in a cross-compatible way. You can only load them first, then filter them to just one, which makes very little sense if you're trying to avoid loading all of them in the first place. So, in general, the answer to your question is "no", unfortunately. Some exchanges execute more than one request, but they don't really fetch markets one by one.

if __name__ == "__main__":

P.S.

```

```

This is also a bad approach:

```
            from_timestamp += len(candles) * minute
```

This is a much better way:

```
from_timestamp = ohlcv[-1][0] + minute
```

Proof:

```Python
import os
import sys
import time
import pandas as pd
from pandas import ExcelWriter


root = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))
sys.path.append(root + '/python')

import ccxt  # noqa: E402

msec = 1000
minute = 60 * msec
hold = 30

exchange = ccxt.binance({
    'rateLimit': 10000,
    'enableRateLimit': True,
    # 'verbose': True,
})

def run():
    from_datetime = '2017-01-01 00:00:00'
    from_timestamp = exchange.parse8601(from_datetime)
    data = []
    now = exchange.milliseconds()

    while from_timestamp < now:
        writer = ExcelWriter('1min.xlsx')
        try:
            print(from_timestamp)
            print(exchange.milliseconds(), 'Fetching candles starting from', exchange.iso8601(from_timestamp), from_timestamp)
            candles = exchange.fetch_ohlcv('BTC/USDT', '1m', from_timestamp)
            print(from_timestamp)
            #print(candles, from_timestamp)     
            print(exchange.milliseconds(), 'Fetched', len(candles), 'candles')
            first = candles[0][0]
            last = candles[-1][0]
            print('First candle epoch', first, exchange.iso8601(first))
            print('Last candle epoch', last, exchange.iso8601(last))
            from_timestamp = candles[-1][0] + minute
            data += candles

            df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['Timestamp','Open','High','Low','Close', 'Volume'])
            df['Timestamp'] = pd.DataFrame(df['Timestamp'].apply(exchange.iso8601))
            save_excel = df.to_excel(writer, sheet_name='2017_CURRENT')
            writer.save()
            print('1m candles saved')
        except (ccxt.ExchangeError, ccxt.AuthenticationError, ccxt.ExchangeNotAvailable, ccxt.RequestTimeout) as error:

            print('Got an error', type(error).__name__, error.args, ', retrying in', hold, 'seconds...')
            time.sleep(hold)
if __name__ == "__main__":      
    run()
```

**UPD. typos**
Feel free to reopen it if the above does not answer your question.

how to fetch the ohlcv from active candle that still not closed?
i need open ,high and low values from current candle.
i try it in kuCoin, but nothing.

title: How to share rate limit between multiple scripts?
body: Versions not really relevant. This could be a feature request except that I'm not asking for that. I want some input on how this might be done. author: bitnom

comments.body:
It will depend on what exactly you are trying to achieve. Almost definitely, the solution is not extending ccxt library functionality.

Maybe you can thread your scripts and use a global variable to hold last request timestamps, then everytime you make a request in your code (any script) you lock the variable so other scripts cannot proceed with queries before the lock is released from the first call (i.e request is done)

This could be done in Python with the threading module.
Closing this issue for now, but feel free to reach out for any other questions

title: Status for a partially-filled canceled order
body: Hi, a simple question... Which status should have an order that has been partially-filled and then canceled?
author: snake575

comments.body:
Hi! 

> Which status should have an order that has been partially-filled and then canceled?

The status in that case should be `canceled`, with `amount > 0`, `filled > 0`, `remaining > 0`, `filled < amount`. Let us know if that does not answer the question.

title: Newer versions of ccxt on x86
body:

What could be the case here? Maybe ccxt uses a newer version of node, which is not supported on x86 architecture anymore?

Thanks in advance.
author: Cleric334

comments.body:
> Is there a way I still can run ccxt on x86?

Unfortunately, not at this time, because the timestamp/nonce is in milliseconds in most cases. A milliseconds timestamp doesn't fit in 32 bits.

title: question about symbol mapping
body:
As I understand it we are using coinmarketcap as  arbiter for sorting out which coin owns which 3/4 letter symbol.  The one with the highest market cap wins, the other uses its name as its symbol.

My concern is that a coin that is competing for a symbol with another, may at some point rise up the coinmarketcap ranks forcing the ccxt code to swap symbols around.  Worse still, if they have a similar rank, but go up and down slightly the symbols assigned to the currencies might repeatedly reverse.

Would using coin names ('e' Bitcoin instead of BTC) not be a more stable solution?  I know coins have been known to change names, so this isn't a perfect solution either.  But it's rare.
author: npomfret

comments.body:
> As I understand it we are using coinmarketcap as arbiter for sorting out which coin owns which 3/4 letter symbol. The one with the highest market cap wins, the other uses its name as its symbol.

Right.

> My concern is that a coin that is competing for a symbol with another, may at some point rise up the coinmarketcap ranks forcing the ccxt code to swap symbols around. 

We have had a couple of these issues earlier. However, this is still a pretty rare occasion when two coins have the same token and the market cap switch takes place (effectively making one of the CMC tokens overtake the unified symbol).

> Worse still, if they have a similar rank, but go up and down slightly the symbols assigned to the currencies might repeatedly reverse.

Never had this before with duplicate symbols. The situation is still possible, theoretically. But, practically, it rarely occurs, if ever. We haven't seen this (yet).

> Would using coin names ('e' Bitcoin instead of BTC) not be a more stable solution? I know coins have been known to change names, so this isn't a perfect solution either. But it's rare.

We've seen them renaming XRB‚Üê‚ÜíNANO, DRK‚Üê‚ÜíDASH, BCC‚Üê‚ÜíBCH, but yeah, this is quite rare. The chances for a renaming are approximately the same as with dupe-symbols overtaking the marketcap, I think. Yet still, I also think switching symbols from 3/4 codes to token names would add to confusion among traders and would make maintaining and debugging much harder ‚Äì you'll have to map them back-and-forth, which is hard when your codenaming system differs from the rest of the world.

Let me know if this does not answer your question!
Thanks @kroitor

title: Binance get all order history
body:
- OS: Windows 10
- Programming Language version: PHP 7.1.11
- CCXT version: 1.13.78
- Exchange: Binance

Hi, first of all, thanks for this wonderful repo!

Though I am wondering whats the best way to get all my recent orders, or all my previous orders using ccxt.

I tried using fetch_closed_orders and fetch_my_trades, but both only work if the symbol specified. Is there any method similiar as fetch_open_orders which require no symbol for this?

Best Regards
author: ilman

comments.body:
Hi ilman!

You can try: 

`exchange.options["warnOnFetchOpenOrdersWithoutSymbol"] = false;`

Then will be possible to call  `fetchOpenOrders` without specifying the symbol.

> Is there any method similiar as fetch_open_orders which require no symbol for this?

No. Half of the exchanges will require a symbol for those calls. You will have to remember which orders you have placed, and then you have to check those particular symbols for updates in the orders with `fetch`-methods. In other words, you will have to fetch them one-by-one for all symbols of your interest, therefore you will either fetch the data for all binance symbols sequentially, or filter all markets  and fetch only the data for the filtered ones (according to your own filtering rules).

Let us know if that does not answer your question.

title: fetchOrderHistory fail on symbol='' ; used to work
body:
Hi!

Im not sure if this is a defect, its a change in behaviour.

Against sandbox api on GDAX the following used to work to fetch all OpenOrders
`all_open_orders = exchange.fetchOpenOrders(symbol='', since="", limit="", params={})`

Now the following error is returned. 
`ccxt/base/exchange.py", line 312, in raise_error
    raise exception_type(output)
ccxt.base.errors.ExchangeError: gdax No market symbol`

Requesting without symbol passed empty works as prior behaviour 
`all_open_orders = exchange.fetchOpenOrders(since="", limit="", params={})`

- OS: Ubuntu 18:04
- Programming Language version: 3.6 Python
- CCXT version: 1.17.85
- Exchange: gdax sandbox
- Method: fetchOpenOrders
author: creslinux

comments.body:
@creslinux we don't accept empty strings in the args anywhere, so, if you want to pass an empty symbol, it should be None: `exchange.fetchOpenOrders(symbol=None, since=None, limit=None, params={})`. You're right, it did work with some exchanges earlier, but the fact that it used to work with an empty string is more like a bug. It should not accept empty strings, really. None-values are used to indicate the absence of the value instead. With an empty string the behavior is undefined for now.

Let us know if it does not answer the question. Thx!)

title: Bitmex fetch_ohlcv return only old data from 2015
body:

- Programming Language version: php 7.2
- CCXT version: 1.14.62
- Exchange: Bitmex
- Method: fetch_ohlcv


Hi! I try get OHLC data from Bitmex with since = null and get always old data, between September 25, 2015, September 29, 2015. If I try use since, I don't receive any data or segment between September 25, 2015, September 29, 2015

`require_once "vendor/autoload.php";`
`$exchange  = new \ccxt\bitmex  (array ('apiKey' => 'xxx','secret'=>'yyy'));`
`$limit = 100;`
`$since = $exchange->milliseconds()-$limit*60*1000;`
`$symbol = 'BTC/USD';`
`$timeframe = '1h';`
`$params = array('partial'=> False);`
`$ohlcv = $exchange->fetch_ohlcv('BTC/USD', '1h', $since);`
`print_r($ohlcv);`

Empty date!

if calculate $since like
`$since = microtime()-1000*60*60*24;`
receive segment between September 25, 2015, September 29, 2015 

`{`
`     0: {`
`          0: "2015-09-25T13:00:00.000Z",`
`          1: "239.99",`
`          2: "239.99",`
`          3: "237.36",`
`          4: "237.45",`
`          5: "11501"`
`     },`
`     1: {`
`          0: "2015-09-25T14:00:00.000Z",`
`          1: "237.45",`
`          2: "237.05",`
`          3: "236.08",`
`          4: "236.08",`
`          5: "22625"`
`     },`
`     2: {`
`          0: "2015-09-25T15:00:00.000Z",`
`          1: "236.08",`
`          2: "236.52",`
`          3: "236.1",`
`          4: "236.34",`
`          5: "17434"`
`     },`
`     3: {`
`          0: "2015-09-25T16:00:00.000Z",`
`          1: "236.34",`
`          2: "236.13",`
`          3: "235.44",`
`          4: "235.71",`
`          5: "26900"`
`     }`
`...`
author: lliypuk

comments.body:
You're not calculating your $since value correctly. It has to be in **milliseconds** in UTC.

```PHP
$since = $exchange->milliseconds()-$limit*60*1000;  // why only 60 seconds (60000 milliseconds) here?
```

‚Üë You're fetching 1h candles starting from 60 seconds (1 minute) ago? One hour has not passed yet since last 60 seconds, so it will reply with zero hourly-candles (an empty array).

This is not a correct way of calculating the since argument, either, because it will use microseconds instead of milliseconds:

```PHP
$since = microtime()-1000*60*60*24;  // why microtime here?
```

Correct ways of setting the since are shown below:

```PHP
mbp:ccxt igorkroitor$ php -a
Interactive shell
php > include_once ('./ccxt.php')
php > ;
php > date_default_timezone_set ('UTC');
php > $id = '\\ccxt\\bitmex';
php > $exchange = new $id ();
php > $limit = 100;
php > $hour_duration_in_milliseconds = 60 * 60 * 1000; // not 60 * 1000, but 60 * 60 * 1000 !
php > $since = $exchange->milliseconds () - $limit * $hour_duration_in_milliseconds;
php > $ohlcvs = $exchange->fetch_ohlcv ('BTC/USD', '1h', $since);
php > echo $exchange->iso8601($ohlcvs[0][0]) . "\n"; // print first candle timestamp as a string
2018-08-02T09:00:00.000Z
```

‚Üë 100 hours ago, exactly.

If you omit the `$since` argument, it will output 100 candles from the beginning of their trading that was in 2015...

```PHP
php > $ohlcvs = $exchange->fetch_ohlcv ('BTC/USD', '1h');
php > echo $exchange->iso8601($ohlcvs[0][0]) . "\n"; // print first candle timestamp as a string
2015-09-25T12:00:00.000Z
php >
```

In other words, you should pay more attention to you basic milliseconds-arithmetics.

Hope this answers your question. Let us know if not.

Thanks for your answer, you are right, I took mistake with calculate milliseconds in hour. Now I use this code: 
`$exchange = new \ccxt\bitmex (array ('apiKey' => 'xxx','secret'=>'yyy'));`
` $limit = 100;`
` $hour_duration_in_milliseconds = 60 * 60 * 1000; `
` $since = $exchange->milliseconds () - $limit * $hour_duration_in_milliseconds;`
` $ohlcvs = $exchange->fetch_ohlcv ('BTC/USD', '1h', $since);`
 `var_dump($ohlcvs);`

and it is always empty too. I don't understand what do wrong

It is really strange, but yes. This is my code:

`date_default_timezone_set ('UTC'); `
`include_once ('/vendor/ccxt/ccxt.php');`
`$id = '\\ccxt\\bitmex';`
`$exchange = new $id ();`
`$since = $exchange->milliseconds() - 100 * 60 * 60 * 1000;`
`$ohlcvs = $exchange->fetch_ohlcv('BTC/USD', '1h', $since);`
`var_dump($ohlcvs);`
`echo $exchange->iso8601($ohlcvs[0][0]) . "\n";`

and var_dump is `array(0) { }`
... Any ideas?
@lliypuk ok then, let's try updating to the most recent version of CCXT first. Is it still empty with 1.17.83?
Oh, sorry, before created issues, I try change class bitmex for experiment and forgot about it. Now, I changed it back and  fetch_ohlcv work good! Sorry, for spend your time and thanks for your help!

title: Storing API secret
body:
Hello,

Is there a convenient way to store an API key/secret on a forked repository?  I want to keep a file with all of my keys/secrets in the same repo so my first idea was to include the file in the primary .gitignore.  However, my concern is that if I keep my fork in sync with this repo, changes I made in .gitignore will be overwritten every time I sync, unhiding my key/secret file.

Sincerely,
Carter
author: pegahcarter

comments.body:
`keys.local.json` is in .gitignore already.

Additionally, if you make it a symbolic link then you're pretty safe even in case it gets removed from .gitignore and you accidentally commit it.

title: `cost_to_precision()` uses `markets[symbol]['precision']['price']`?
author: mkoistinen

comments.body: No it's not a typo, because exchanges will very rarely provide cost precision. Think logically, cost is `amount * price` that is the same units as price (represented in the same currency, therefore  both `cost` and `price` have that currency's precision).
OK. Thanks.

title: 'timestamp' in parse_orders should be descending
body:
in exchange.py

    def parse_orders(self, orders, market=None, since=None, limit=None):
        array = self.to_array(orders)
        array = [self.parse_order(order, market) for order in array]
        **array = self.sort_by(array, 'timestamp')**
        symbol = market['symbol'] if market else None
        return self.filter_by_symbol_since_limit(array, symbol, since, limit)

the array is better  descending sort by timestamp

because if you use 'limit' params to fetch_closed_orders, the order of orders will be chaos
author: ouyangtianzuo

comments.body: Sorry, but we don't agree. The logic behind it is to fetch `limit` rows starting from `since` timestamp into the future (not backwards into the past). Earlier, to satisfy numerous requests from users, we've switched from what you proposed to ascending sorting order in all methods returning trades, orders, candles and other arrays. Hope this answers your question. Let us know if not.

title: Bittrex methods  XToPrecision return float instead of string
body:
- Programming Language version: Python
- CCXT version: ccxt-1.16.57
- Exchange: bittrex, bitfinex
- Method: XToPrecision

Hi,
I just found that, while all other exchanges I used so far return a string on the method XToPrecision (fee,cost,amount etc), the **bittrex** exchange returns a float!

```
ct = ccxt.bittrex()
ct.loadMarkets()
ct.costToPrecision('ETH/BTC',0.00100000)
```
--> float
```
ct = ccxt.binance()
ct.loadMarkets()
ct.costToPrecision('ETH/BTC',0.00100000)
```
--> string (also for other exchanges such as kraken, kucoin and bitfined

Also it seems that the **bitfinex** feeToPrecision is not working, as it always returns a key error for any symbol.
author: MarcelBeining

comments.body:
> I just found that, while all other exchanges I used so far return a string on the method XToPrecision (fee,cost,amount etc), the bittrex exchange returns a float!

That's right, but you should not rely on the type of the output of that method, really, because it will generate an exchange-specific return-type anyway. Some exchanges will require floats, others will require strings. 

> Also it seems that the bitfinex feeToPrecision is not working, as it always returns a key error for any symbol.

You should loadMarkets for it first.

Let us know if this does not answer your question.

Hi, ok thanks.
However concerning bitfinex, I actually **did** load the market:
```
ct = ccxt.bitfinex()
ct.loadMarkets()
ct.feeToPrecision('ETH/BTC',0.00100000)
```
--> error

> ```ct.feeToPrecision('ETH/BTC',0.00100000)```

‚Üë That's an error, bitfinex uses currency precision for fees instead of pair-precision...

`ct.feeToPrecision('ETH',0.00100000)` or `ct.feeToPrecision('BTC',0.00100000)` will work.

In other words, I'm telling you: you should not rely on any non-documented methods, as most of them are there for internal exchange-specific needs. Instead of using `feeToPrecision`, you should rather calculate the fee with `calculateFee`, for example. This particular aspect is very hard to unify and the work on it is still in progress.

We are thinking of redesigning this a bit, namely, remove amountToPrecision and priceToPrecision and use a generic toPrecision method, that would accept a currency code or a pair and a numeric value and some other arguments, maybe, and would work in a unified way for amounts, prices, costs and fees. We would document the new set of methods and you could build upon it then. Hope to do it soon (need to think a little more on this). And will let you know, of course. In the meantime, you have to improvise and be creative.

title: Is there a possibility to fetch OHLCV for all symbols at exchange at once?
body: It is mean that if exchange has 300 markets and 1s ratelimit, i must spend as minimum 300 seconds to load OHLCV for all market?
author: viogull

comments.body:
> Is there a possibility to fetch OHLCV for all symbols at exchange at once?

Not really, very few exchanges will allow that. 

> It is mean that if exchange has 300 markets and 1s ratelimit, i must spend as minimum 300 seconds to load OHLCV for all market?

Yes. But because OHLCV is a public call and does not require authentication, you can parallelise that. Say, have 30 computers each issuing a call at 1s ratelimit, thus it will take 10 seconds... 300 computers = 1 second... and so on...

title: CCXT structure for meteor applications
body:
- OS: Ubuntu 16.04
- Programming Language version: Meteor.js 1.7.03
- CCXT version: Latest 1.15 or whatever
- Exchange: Most of them
- Method: Pulling Transaction Data, and most public pricing endpoints

It's not exactly an issue and you recommend to read the manual for these things, but I could find any help for this.

I wanted to know how would you structure this library in a meteor application. I wanted to know how to structure the server side code so that I could pull transaction history from the private endpoints at the user's request. The user would be able to choose their desired exchange and it will allow them to put in their API key and secret.

I also wanted to know how to structure to pull pricing data from public endpoints. I intend to make a live feed for this data.

Do I separate the files based off the exchange or methods and call the files required dependant on the action. 

Is there an example or guide that I could base it off of or any recommendations.
author: DanMan259

comments.body:
> I wanted to know how would you structure this library in a meteor application.

Actually, you don't structure this library, you structure your app.

And this leads to the question... do you have Meteor issue or ccxt issue? I mean, do you have experience of writing Meteor apps? Because, if you don't then you'll probably need to seek an advice elsewhere. Not because we're unwilling to answer, I just wouldn't expect to find Meteor experts here.

> Is there an example or guide that I could base it off of or any recommendations.

As for ccxt there are plenty of examples in `/examples/js/` folder. They are neat and it's wise to take a look at them.

I believe that if:
1) you can write a Meteor app that makes use of a DB (or any other async resource)
2) you can write a minimalistic ccxt script that queries an exchange

then replacing DB calls with ccxt calls should not be an issue.
@DanMan259  Is this ok close?

title: Is there a fetch_ticker cache?
body:
I'm trying to update about 100 coin prices across a dozen exchanges. Going one-by-one is obviously inefficient if the exchange API doesn't support individual coin calls.

I was thinking I could either cache the results (I'm fine with 3 minutes) or I'll have to rewrite my script to call the all-at-once exchanges only once, update all the prices, and then call the one-at-a-time exchanges.

I can't find anything in the docs; does such a cache feature exist? How simple would it be to implement?
author: presence35

comments.body:
> I can't find anything in the docs; does such a cache feature exist?

Nope, we don't cache them in the library, because caching them in userland is trivial.

> How simple would it be to implement?

Very simple, if you know your programming language well. If you're doing this in PHP, that would just require creating a shared assoc array of tickers by symbol, protecting it with mutexes and writing from your threads to that assoc array directly.

One thing to note here: caching real-time data is ok for analysis purposes, however, you don't really want to trade tickers that are several minutes old, for obvious reasons.

Let us know if it does not answer your question.

title: How to make async data fetching work with multi-threading
body:
I have been following the async examples and been fetching market data and order book data successfully. I now have a problem with threading. I struggle to make async code work with threading. A snippet of my code is like this where loadGDAX() will work perfectly when invoked on its own but not in a thread:

def loadGDAX():
    exchange = ccxt.gdax({
        'enableRateLimit': True,  # this option enables the built-in rate limiter
    })
    asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(loadTickerImpl(exchange, 'ETH/USD', 'GDAX.txt'))
    
def test1():
    print(datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(time.time()).strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'))

number=7
p1 = threading.Thread(target=loadGDAX)
p2 = threading.Thread(target=test1)
p1.start()
p2.start()
p1.join()
p2.join()

I don't think this is a very difficult problem but my limited python knowledge is not helping.
I will greatly appreciate it if anybody can help.
author: cowboyjj

comments.body:
Async python and multithreading often break each other. 

Your problem is that you are using asyncio.get_event_loop() inside a thread (you will get an error saying no event loop found or something like that). Define the event loop outside of the multithreaded function to fix this.

I apologize since I realize I may not have provided a good context to my question. Basically I want to have one function fetching data non-stop and writing data to a file, and another function loading back those data from file and performing some data analysis on the data. There is a third function which should handle the trade (buy/sell) transactions with the exchange. I want to have all these three functions running in parallel on three different threads but I am not able to get it working.

Define three functions that do that and start them in different threads?

> I struggle to make async code work with threading. 

could you post the error at least..

Hello frosty, thanks a lot for replying. 

The error was exactly as you described in your first post, 'no event loop found' (or something like that. Having seen your first comment I've been trying to define the loop outside. Also I've been trying to use 'concurrent.futures.ThreadPoolExecutor' which seem to work in some google search results. However as we speak I am still struggling to put these things together ...

Define the event loop outside the async function and reference it directly instead of using asyncio.get_event_loop. Also you need to use `asyncio.run_coroutine_threadsafe(coro(), loop=loop)` to wrap future tasks if you want it to work (trust me on this it will save a headache down the line)

Cool. Thanks Frosty.

I will try. If you or any helper can provide some skeleton code or code snippet so that I see how things are put together it will be most helpful.

@frosty00 , I currently use sys.exit() to close all my exchange coroutines. I tried using your function but get the following error: 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "app.py", line 710, in <module>
    close_all()
  File "app.py", line 691, in close_all
    if not network.EVENT_LOOP.is_running():
NameError: name 'network' is not defined
```
So I tried installing the network module and now I get this error: 
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "app.py", line 711, in <module>
    close_all()
  File "app.py", line 692, in close_all
    if not network.EVENT_LOOP.is_running():
AttributeError: module 'network' has no attribute 'EVENT_LOOP'
```

Yeah sorry network is just a file I have in my project. 

EVENT_LOOP is the same as `asyncio.get_event_loop()` or `asyncio.new_event_loop()`
Closing this for now, feel free to reopen it if needed, or just questions if you have more. Thx to @frosty00 for the support!

title: Accurately establish min trade limit for both base and quote
body:
I am creating a bot (testing with Cryptopia) that starts with one currency (BTC per my development thus far) and trades amongst every market for said currency regardless of whether the currency is the base or quote. In order to establish the minimum reserve needed for at least one trade in each market I need to sum up the minimum limits. For each market I need to determine whether the min amount or min cost is larger. For example:

BSTY/BTC
MinAmount: 1.0E-8 BSTY
MinCost:   0.0005 BTC

BTC/USDT
MinAmount: 1.0E-8 BTC
MinCost:   1 USDT

The first market has a quote of BTC, whereas the second a base of BTC. I have been struggling to find the most accurate way to estimate the BTC value of the non-BTC amount/cost. Would I use the most current price? Per the manual:

```
# Get current best price (query market price) and calculate bid/ask spread
$orderbook = $exchange->fetch_order_book ($exchange->symbols[0]);
$bid = count ($orderbook['bids']) ? $orderbook['bids'][0][0] : NULL;
$ask = count ($orderbook['asks']) ? $orderbook['asks'][0][0] : NULL;
$spread = ($bid && $ask) ? $ask - $bid : NULL;
```

If so, would the estimated BTC equivalent of the minimum amount (before fees) in the first example be established via the following?

`$btcMinAmountEquiv = $minAmount * $bid;`

The above seems logical to me yet the return is such so far below the minimum cost that I can't help to think that my reasoning is flawed. It's worth noting that there will be several points in my script in which I need to estimate the BTC equivalent for a non-BTC cryptocurrency.

Thank you very much for your help.

- OS: ubuntu0.16.04.1
- Programming Language version: PHP 7.0.30-0
- CCXT version: 10.1 2017-11-06
- Exchange: Cryptopia
- Method: N/A
author: phoenix-violeus

comments.body:
Essentially what I'm asking:
What's the most logical way to estimate the current value of an amount in one currency in terms of the second currency?

title: What is the best way to keep up-to-date a database with OHLCV data ?
body:
Hello,

I would like to build a database with OHLCV data (1d, 4h, 1h) from multiple exchanges and this is a lot of data to collect periodically.

A solution could be to calculate 1d and 4h candles from the 1h data to limit the number of query but still it will take a very long time to fetch thousand of candles in 1h. Do you think there is an alternative option to do this ? For example `fetch_tickers()` returns symbols details including OHLCV for every symbols of an exchange in a single API call, but unfortunnatly there are exchanges that do not support this function, and I'm not not sure what is the timeframe of this OHLCV and if it is consistent for every exchanges.

Thanks,
author: Kinzowa

comments.body:
> A solution could be to calculate 1d and 4h candles from the 1h data to limit the number of query 

Yep )

> but still it will take a very long time to fetch thousand of candles in 1h.

Nope ) Just do a quick calculation: 1h candle = 24 candles per day = 720 / month = 8640 / year.
I doubt that you will ever need to operate on a whole year at once. For modern dbs fetching 8k rows is a piece of cake. You can host it on your netpad... Of course, you're going to store and fetch multiple pairs and all that, but still, come on, it's the 21st century, 100k rows shouldn't be a problem.
Hi Igor, ye but there are 1000+ symbols to fetch every hour (multiple exchanges) and this is a lot of API requests.

> but is there are 1000+ symbols to fetch every hour 

No need to fetch them every hour. You can fetch the entire day (24 hours of 1h-candles) in one call per day. 1000 calls per day is a piece of cake. Moreover, with most of adequate exchanges you can fetch a month of 1h-candles in one call. And you're not going to trade the inadequate exchanges. Also, you're probably not going to have enough funding for trading all those pairs, and you will meet all sorts of restrictions along the way, so with very little brainwork you can filter and reduce your list of pairs by a factor of 2 to 10. That's just 100 pairs of your interest. 864000 rows per year. Any modern PC can handle this easily (if you're not wasting your resources and burning CPU cycles on purpose).
I'd close this for now if you don't mind. Feel free to reopen it if needed or just ask questions. Thx!

The idea is to backtest trading strategies so yes I'll need all those pairs. Another constraint I have is fast trading decisions so any solution that takes too much time to fecth all the data is not suitable, even with a minimum timeframe of 4h. I think I'll try a combination of the two methods with `fetch_ohlcv()` to get proper 4h candles and `fetch_tickers()` to retrieve the latest price available of every symbols in one call, every 1h or every 4h. 

I can remain closed, thanks.

title: [BitMEX] Getting balance of altcoin positions
body:
- OS: Mac OS X High Sierra
- Programming Language version: Python 3.6
- CCXT version: 1.13.66
- Exchange: BitMEX
- Method: fetch_balance()

After looking through the different exchanges code, it appears that `fetch_balance()` returns whatever the exchange API's response is, without the ability to specify a specific coin. For most exchanges, I can do something like `exchange.fetch_balance()['free']['ETH']`.

But for BitMEX, that only gives works for BTC, so I have to use `bitmex.private_get_position({'symbol':'ETHM18'}[0]['currentQty'])` which is quite troublesome as I have to include a unique case for BitMEX each time.

If this issue only affects BitMEX (I'm not sure if that's the case), are there plans to update `fetch_balance()` in the bitmex class to call `private_get_position()`? That would allow for `fetch_balance()['free']['<symbol>']` to be a unified method of getting altcoin positions.
author: yidkato

comments.body:
In general, we don't have margin/leveraged trading in the unified CCXT API yet, but we are working on it, hope to add it as soon as possible. In the meantime, you really should use implicit methods like you do already, if you want to implement a position-trading algo. 

Hope it answers your questions.
